EdgeSync performs scheduled updates so that the information in ADAM remains current.
The amount of battery power left on the system.
The amount of battery power left on the system.
In programming, the order and sequence of input and output.
An option that allows the user to specify the degree of transparency of an image.

A tested, cumulative set of hotfixes, security updates, critical updates, and updates packaged together for easy deployment. A rollup generally targets a specific area, such as security, or component of a product, such as Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS).
The date after which information or a resource is no longer valid.

A predefined set of harmonized colors that you can apply to text and objects. Text and objects with an applied scheme color will change automatically when you switch to a new color scheme or modify the current color scheme.
A table inserted within a table cell. If you use a table to lay out a page, and you want to use another table to arrange the information, you can insert a nested table.
A document listing common questions and answers on a particular subject.
To bring information from one system or program into another. The system or program receiving the data must somehow support the internal format or structure of the data.
A meaningful shorthand that makes it easier to understand the purpose of a cell reference, constant, formula, or table, each of which may be difficult to comprehend at first glance.
An object embedded within a compound document in which only a single piece of content can be active.
The parameters of a Microsoft Dynamics CRM workflow that define the circumstances in which the workflow performs its actions.
A feature that heightens the color contrast of some text and images on your computer screen, making those items more distinct and easier to identify.
A queue that is used to hold messages that being delivered to a Mailbox server or remote location. A delivery queue is created for each unique message destination.
A reusable magnetic storage medium. The floppy disk used today is the rigid 3.5-inch microfloppy that holds 1.44 MB. It is called floppy because the first varieties were housed in bendable jackets.
A reusable magnetic storage medium. The floppy disk used today is the rigid 3.5-inch microfloppy that holds 1.44 MB. It is called floppy because the first varieties were housed in bendable jackets.

An item that resides in a folder that uses an event sink. The item provides the store with information that includes what events will trigger the sink, the name of the sink, and options such as restrictions for when the event will fire.

A name that uniquely identifies an object by using the relative distinguished name for the object, plus the names of container objects and domains that contain the object. The distinguished name identifies the object as well as its location in a tree. Every object in Active Directory has a distinguished name.
A privacy relationship setting that allows the most amount of information to be viewed.

In some Internet newsgroups and mailing lists, a person through whom all messages are filtered before they are distributed to the members of the news-group or list. The moderator discards or edits any messages that are not considered appropriate.
A node with subordinate node(s), called children.
The combined data from an Office Outlook user's Safe Senders List, Safe Recipients List, Blocked Senders List, and external contacts, that is stored in Outlook and in the Exchange mailbox.
A service that enables an Internet user to participate in a conversation online in real time with other users.
To disconnect an item from a record, or a record from another record.
Pertaining to a user engaged in a phone conversation.
A system that records and stores telephone messages in a user mailbox.
A system that records and stores telephone messages in a user mailbox.
A system that records and stores telephone messages in a user mailbox.
An alphanumeric identifier that is used to determine whether a record is unique. Each matchcode is derived from the data in selected fields in a record.
The process of selecting nonadjacent and adjacent files and objects.
A sound emitted by the receiver of a telephone that indicates that a number can be dialed.
A mode of setup that allows network administrators to silently deploy to client computers.
A mode of setup that allows network administrators to silently deploy to client computers.
A portable computer that combines a processor, screen, and keyboard in a single case. The screen folds down onto the keyboard when not in use.
In operating systems, the process of reserving memory for use by a program.

The quality of sameness or equivalence, in the case of computers usually referring to an error-checking procedure in which the number of 1s must always be the same --either even or odd-- for each group of bits transmitted without error.
A shaded outline that appears behind an object or text and creates the illusion of depth.
A shaded outline that appears behind an object or text and creates the illusion of depth.
A photo organizer used to view, manage, and edit digital pictures.
The — character, based on the width of an uppercase M and used primarily to set off sentence elements.

An Intel microprocessor that uses explicitly parallel instruction set computing and 64-bit memory addressing. "Itanium-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium processor. "Itanium2-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium2 processor. "Itanium architecture-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium and Itanium2 processors.
The representation of all the instances of a particular record. When changes are made to a record type, those changes will affect all individual records of that type.
The representation of all the instances of a particular record. When changes are made to a record type, those changes will affect all individual records of that type.

A grouping of alphabetic, numeric, and other characters that have some relationship in common. For example, the standard ASCII character set includes letters, numbers, symbols, and control codes that make up the ASCII coding scheme.
A family of Microsoft Visual Studio add-in software that allows developers to use Visual Basic and Visual C# to develop and customize applications built on the Microsoft .NET Framework.

termGrp.term: Microsoft Visual Studio Tools for Applications
Microsoft® Visual Studio® Tools for Applications

descripGrp.descrip: A family of Microsoft Visual Studio add-in software that allows developers to use Visual Basic and Visual C# to develop and customize applications built on the Microsoft .NET Framework.
A family of Microsoft Visual Studio add-in software that allows developers to use Visual Basic and Visual C# to develop and customize applications built on the Microsoft .NET Framework.
The vertical bar at the right of a window that users can click to move through a document.
The vertical bar at the right of a window that users can click to move through a document.

An application commonly used for budgets, forecasting, and other finance-related tasks that organizes data values using cells, where the relationships between cells are defined by formulas. A change to one cell produces changes to related cells. Spreadsheet programs usually provide graphing capabilities for output and a variety of formatting options for text, numeric values, and graph features.

An application commonly used for budgets, forecasting, and other finance-related tasks that organizes data values using cells, where the relationships between cells are defined by formulas. A change to one cell produces changes to related cells. Spreadsheet programs usually provide graphing capabilities for output and a variety of formatting options for text, numeric values, and graph features.
A file that contains configuration information for a specific user, such as desktop settings, persistent network connections, and application settings.
An element of workflow logic that specifies the event or task that should be performed by the workflow jobs started by the workflow.
A copy of a database that is a member of a replica set and can be synchronized with other replicas in the set.
A performer of a song or other audio recording.

A device that converts sound waves into analog electrical signals. Additional hardware can convert the microphone's output into digital data that a computer can process; for example, to record multimedia documents or analyze the sound signal.
The process of adding software to a computer system.
A tool or feature that allows users to see different fonts, typography formats, and lettershapes that display on the computer and/or on Web sites.
The number of bits transmitted every second, used as a measure of the speed at which a device, such as a modem, can transfer data.
The number of bits transmitted every second, used as a measure of the speed at which a device, such as a modem, can transfer data.
A keyboard key that moves the cursor to the left, one character at a time, usually erasing each character as it moves.
A secondary report that is displayed when a user clicks an item in a report. Detailed data is displayed in the same report.
Of, pertaining to, or being an object or image having or appearing to have all three spatial dimensions (length, width, and depth).
Of, pertaining to, or being an object or image having or appearing to have all three spatial dimensions (length, width, and depth).
Of, pertaining to, or being an object or image having or appearing to have all three spatial dimensions (length, width, and depth).
The complementary tasks of gathering and distributing data. Input is data that is acquired from a device or entered by the user through a device. Output is data that is sent to a device.
The complementary tasks of gathering and distributing data. Input is data that is acquired from a device or entered by the user through a device. Output is data that is sent to a device.

The creation of an image containing geometric models, using color and shading to give the image a realistic look. Usually part of a geometric modeling package such as a CAD program, rendering uses mathematics to describe the location of a light source in relation to the object and to calculate the way in which the light would create highlights, shading, and variations in color. The degree of realism can range from opaque, shaded polygons to images approximating photographs in their complexity.
A feature that provides detailed Web site statistics and reports related to the subscriber's Web site.

A technology for transferring and sharing information among applications. When an object, such as an image file created with a paint program, is linked to a compound document, such as a spreadsheet or a document created with a word processing program, the document contains only a reference to the object; any changes made to the contents of a linked object will be seen in the compound document. When an object is embedded in a compound document, the document contains a copy of the object; any changes made to the contents of the original object will not be seen in the compound document unless the embedded object is updated.

A technology for transferring and sharing information among applications. When an object, such as an image file created with a paint program, is linked to a compound document, such as a spreadsheet or a document created with a word processing program, the document contains only a reference to the object; any changes made to the contents of a linked object will be seen in the compound document. When an object is embedded in a compound document, the document contains a copy of the object; any changes made to the contents of the original object will not be seen in the compound document unless the embedded object is updated.
A small device used to store information. USB flash drives plug into computer USB ports so you can copy information to or from them, making it easy to share and transport information.
A small device used to store information. USB flash drives plug into computer USB ports so you can copy information to or from them, making it easy to share and transport information.
The set of possible values that you can specify for an independent variable in a function, or for a database attribute.

On the World Wide Web, a block of data that a Web server stores on a client system. When a user returns to the same Web site, the browser sends a copy of the cookie back to the server. Cookies are used to identify users, to instruct the server to send a customized version of the requested Web page, to submit account information for the user, and for other administrative purposes.
The ability of a resource to produce an amount of output in a specified amount of time.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.
Software that monitors activity, such as keystrokes or screen images. These programs are often installed by the computer owner or administrator, and are only a threat if they are unexpected.

A directory of information about data sets, files, or a database. It usually describes where a data set, file or database entity is located and may also include other information, such as the type of device on which each data set or file is stored.
A feature that enables customers to store financial information and perform financial transactions in more than one form of currency in a single implementation.
A defined set of values that Microsoft Office Outlook uses to keep track of user accounts.
A potential revenue-generating event, or sale to an account, that needs to be tracked through a sales process to completion.

A business that supplies Internet connectivity services to individuals, businesses, and other organizations. An ISP provides a telephone number, a user name, a password, and other connection information so that users can access the Internet through the ISP's computers.

A business that supplies Internet connectivity services to individuals, businesses, and other organizations. An ISP provides a telephone number, a user name, a password, and other connection information so that users can access the Internet through the ISP's computers.

A business that supplies Internet connectivity services to individuals, businesses, and other organizations. An ISP provides a telephone number, a user name, a password, and other connection information so that users can access the Internet through the ISP's computers.

A business that supplies Internet connectivity services to individuals, businesses, and other organizations. An ISP provides a telephone number, a user name, a password, and other connection information so that users can access the Internet through the ISP's computers.

A business that supplies Internet connectivity services to individuals, businesses, and other organizations. An ISP provides a telephone number, a user name, a password, and other connection information so that users can access the Internet through the ISP's computers.

A business that supplies Internet connectivity services to individuals, businesses, and other organizations. An ISP provides a telephone number, a user name, a password, and other connection information so that users can access the Internet through the ISP's computers.
Depending on values embedded in the program code rather than on values that can be input and changed by the user.

Self-propagating malicious code that can automatically distribute itself from one computer to another through network connections. A worm can take harmful action, such as consuming network or local system resources, possibly causing a denial of service attack.

A process in which Unified Messaging dials calls. Unified Messaging generally receives calls, but sometimes dials calls. For example, outdialing occurs when Unified Messaging transfers a call to an auto attendant or a subscriber uses Play-on-Phone from Outlook.

Pertaining to a user who sets their status to Do Not Disturb. For the user's contacts who have a Workgroup privacy relationship, the user is displayed with the Busy icon and Urgent interruptions only text.

A label with sophisticated anti-counterfeiting features that helps the end user identify that the computer uses a validly licensed copy of Microsoft Windows. The product name and a unique product key appear in the center of the label. The OEM must physically attach the COA label to the computer chassis, and it should never be removed from the computer.

A label with sophisticated anti-counterfeiting features that helps the end user identify that the computer uses a validly licensed copy of Microsoft Windows. The product name and a unique product key appear in the center of the label. The OEM must physically attach the COA label to the computer chassis, and it should never be removed from the computer.
A security solution that segregates one portion of a network from another portion, allowing only authorized network traffic to pass through according to traffic filtering rules.

In Windows Presentation Foundation, an event routing strategy where the event instance moves down the element tree (starting at the root of the visual tree and ending with the source). The names of events that use this routing strategy are prefixed with the word "Preview". These events have the same signature as their counterparts that use the bubbling event routing strategy.
A listing of keywords and associated data that point to the location of more comprehensive information, such as files and records on a disk or record keys in a database.

A set of instructions in some computer language intended to be executed on a computer so as to perform some task. The term usually implies a self-contained entity, as opposed to a routine or a library.
A type of trojan that captures or transmits passwords to an attacker.
A standard for providing integrity and confidentiality to IP (Internet Protocol) datagrams. In some circumstances, it can also provide authentication to IP datagrams.

The special identification code printed as a set of vertical bars of differing widths on books, grocery products, and other merchandise. Used for rapid, error-free input in such facilities as libraries, hospitals, and grocery stores, bar codes represent binary information that can be read by an optical scanner. The coding can include numbers, letters, or a combination of the two; some codes include built-in error checking and can be read in either direction.

A software technique for smoothing the jagged appearance of curved or diagonal lines caused by poor resolution on a display screen. Methods of anti-aliasing include surrounding pixels with intermediate shades and manipulating the size and horizontal alignment of the pixels.

A software technique for smoothing the jagged appearance of curved or diagonal lines caused by poor resolution on a display screen. Methods of anti-aliasing include surrounding pixels with intermediate shades and manipulating the size and horizontal alignment of the pixels.

The dynamic alphabet bar that runs along the bottom of the list views in the Microsoft Dynamics CRM Web application window. When a user clicks a letter, the list view filters the available records by that letter.
A control that indicates whether or not an option is selected. A check mark or "x" appears in the box when the option is selected.

An input device with the following features: a flat-bottomed casing designed to be gripped by one hand; one or more buttons on the top; a multidirectional detection device (a ball, laser or optical device) on the bottom; and a cable or wireless connection to the computer.
A utility or feature that aids in accomplishing a task or set of tasks.
A type of CD-ROM that can be written (only once) on a CD recorder and read on a CD-ROM drive.
A type of CD-ROM that can be written (only once) on a CD recorder and read on a CD-ROM drive.
The ability of hardware devices, software packages, or a computer itself to work with network devices or with other hardware devices, software packages, or a computer over a network connection.
A search for data in a table or field using placeholders (such as * or ?).
A feature introduced with Windows 2000 that allows administrators to enforce computer-specific and user-specific settings to domain-based computers.
A category for grouping or describing multimedia or games, such as music categorized as "classical" or "jazz".

A component of a scroll bar that allows the information to be scrolled by defined increments when the user clicks it. The direction of the arrow indicates the direction in which the information scrolls.

A component of a scroll bar that allows the information to be scrolled by defined increments when the user clicks it. The direction of the arrow indicates the direction in which the information scrolls.
A DVD from which the video section can be played on the DVD set top box. When inserted in the PC, the user can access additional features such as games, web links etc.

The name or structure of a field in a database entity. For example, the LASTNAME, FIRSTNAME, and PHONE are attributes of each record in a PhoneList entity. The size of a field and the type of information it contains are also attributes of a database record.
To load a large amount of data, usually in batches, from a data file or repository to another data repository.
A photographic style that renders a photo in brown tones, mimicking the old-fashioned look of photos taken in the early part of the 20th century.
A pattern or mask through which data is passed to separate specified items.
The ~ character.
A hardware type for digital cameras and scanners.
To use for your benefit.
A standard Windows icon that represents a user’s private, usually local, storage.
The ¢ character.
A record of transactions or events that take place within an IT managed environment.
A toolbar that is not attached to the edge of the program window. You can change the shape of some floating toolbars.
Technology that allows machines to recognize and respond to human voice commands.
Technology that allows machines to recognize and respond to human voice commands.
To cause text or an image to visually fade.
A proposed protocol standard that supports authentication and encryption to secure privacy in Internet communications. PCT is similar to the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.
A proposed protocol standard that supports authentication and encryption to secure privacy in Internet communications. PCT is similar to the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.
Pertaining to a process or content that is not associated with an identifiable user or originator.

A computer that acts as a source of information or signals. The host computer provides services, such as news, mail, or data, to computers that connect to it. The term can refer to almost any kind of computer, from a centralized mainframe that is a host to its terminals, to a server that is host to its clients, to a desktop PC that is host to its devices, such as printers and scanners.

A pointing device used mainly but not exclusively for computer games. A joystick has a base, on which control buttons can be mounted, and a vertical stem, which the user can move in any direction to control the movement of an object on the screen.
In reference to one or more computers, connected to a network.
A program that transforms a picture stored in one file format to another format so that it can be displayed in a specific graphics program.
A number that the system assigns to an order for identification purposes.
The location (drive, folder, or directory) to which a file is copied or moved.

A custom word or phrase that the administrator sets for the Content Filter agent to enable the processing of e-mail messages to Exchange Server 2007 mailbox users that contain specific words or phrases.
The location where email is delivered.

A written order on a bank to pay a sum of money from funds in an account. Checks show the name of the company or individual receiving payment, the signature and account number of the person issuing the check, the payment amount and the current date. Checks usually are numbered in sequence.
The process of aligning text along both the left and right margins.
A technology that allows documents to be converted to HTML and displayed in a Web browser when a viewing application is not available.
A datasheet that is nested within another datasheet and that contains data related or joined to the first datasheet.
Protection of a computer system and its data from harm or loss.
Protection of a computer system and its data from harm or loss.
In a newsreader client program, to remove a newsgroup from the list of newsgroups to which upload one subscribes.

A communication method that creates a single activity for distribution to a group of marketing lists, accounts, contacts, or leads. Contrast with a campaign, which supports an end-to-end marketing program that has multiple activities.
The <> characters.

A physical hardware unit that can connect portable computers to a power source and to peripherals, such as a monitor, printer, full-sized keyboard, or mouse. The connection can be wireless or physical.

A physical hardware unit that can connect portable computers to a power source and to peripherals, such as a monitor, printer, full-sized keyboard, or mouse. The connection can be wireless or physical.
The ability to record all communications, including e-mail communications, in an organization for use in the organization's e-mail retention or archival strategy.
The capability of source code or programs developed on a more advanced system or compiler version to be executed or compiled by a less advanced (older) version.

A touch-sensitive screen on your device that can recognize the location of a touch (of a fingertip or stylus, for example) on its surface and translate that touch into a desired action (such as opening an item or moving the cursor).
A rule or procedure for solving a problem.
The action that an Exchange Server 2007 transport rule takes if a disclaimer cannot be applied to an e-mail message as, for example, when a message is encrypted.
A file that contains some pre-defined formatting, layout, and/or text and graphics and that serves as the basis for new documents with a similar look or purpose.
The entire interconnected set of hardware, or the way in which a network is laid out--the manner in which elements are connected.
The entire interconnected set of hardware, or the way in which a network is laid out--the manner in which elements are connected.
A message sent in real time through a network to a private chat area.
A message sent in real time through a network to a private chat area.
An employee who provides service to the customers of the organization or business unit through the opening and resolution of cases, among other activities.

termGrp.term: representante do servizo de atención ao cliente

descripGrp.descrip: To systematically examine files or other data to identify content or patterns that meet specific criteria.
A bar at the top of the Excel window that you use to enter or edit values or formulas in cells or charts. Displays the constant value or formula stored in the active cell.
To copy files to a recordable CD.
A window that displays data from a table, form, query, view, or stored procedure in a row-and-column format.

An outer join in which all the records from the right side of the RIGHT JOIN operation in the query's SQL statement are added to the query's results, even if there are no matching values in the joined field from the table on the left.
The use of computers and data communication equipment to convey messages from one person to another, as by e-mail, voice mail, or fax.
A certification authority that has the ability to issue the intermediate certificates needed to certify the subject identified by the end certificate.
A certification authority that has the ability to issue the intermediate certificates needed to certify the subject identified by the end certificate.
A scripting language used to create interactive or animated content for the Internet, such as games or advanced financial applications.
A toolbar that contains buttons you can use to perform some of the most common tasks in a Microsoft Office program, such as opening, saving, and printing files.
To move an item to a lower level within a tree structure.

An XML format for describing Web services. WSDL allows Web service providers and users of such services to work together easily by enabling the separation of the description of the abstract functionality offered by a service from concrete details of a service description such as "how" and "where" that functionality is offered.

termGrp.term: Linguaxe de descrición de servizos web

descripGrp.descrip: An XML format for describing Web services. WSDL allows Web service providers and users of such services to work together easily by enabling the separation of the description of the abstract functionality offered by a service from concrete details of a service description such as "how" and "where" that functionality is offered.

A plastic (credit card–sized or smaller) device with an embedded microprocessor and a small amount of storage that is used, with an access code, to enable certificate-based authentication. Smart cards securely store certificates, public and private keys, passwords, and other types of personal information.

A plastic (credit card–sized or smaller) device with an embedded microprocessor and a small amount of storage that is used, with an access code, to enable certificate-based authentication. Smart cards securely store certificates, public and private keys, passwords, and other types of personal information.
The color that is currently selected for drawing or displaying text on the screen. In monochrome displays, the foreground color is the color of a bitmap or other graphic.
On a Web page, a grouping of hyperlinks for getting around in that particular Web site.
The individual or account to whom an item is sent.
A video format with the same resolution as traditional television.

Functionality in Exchange Server 2007 that helps the messaging administrator diagnose spam-related problems by applying diagnostic metadata, or "stamps," such as sender-specific information, puzzle validation results, and content filtering results, to messages as they pass through the anti-spam features that filter inbound messages from the Internet.

termGrp.term: carimbo contra correo electrónico non desexado

descripGrp.descrip: A number in the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers and i = sqrt(-1) , so that bi is imaginary unless b = 0.
The window in which the main interaction with an object takes place.
A collection of information that is stored on a computer or device under a single name.

The process of verifying the identity of a user, computer, device, process, or other entity by validating the credentials provided by the entity. Common forms of credentials are digital signatures, smart cards, biometric data, and a combination of user names and passwords.
A string of text that is displayed with one value for each text attribute: typeface, slant, and weight.
The process of converting readable data (plaintext) into a coded form (ciphertext) to prevent it from being read by an unauthorized party.
Software designed to provide access to a computer from a remote location. These programs are often installed by the computer owner or administrator, and are only a risk if unexpected.
A data-entry field on a page. A site visitor supplies information in a field either by typing text or by selecting a field.
A data type used to hold date and time information.
Pertaining to a user, a file or a computer currently connected a server.

A folder in a user’s mailbox to which messaging records management (MRM) has been applied. There are two types of managed folders: “managed default folders” (such as the Inbox) appear, by default, in a user’s Office Outlook mailbox; “managed custom folders” are created by Exchange administrators specifically for MRM. The retention and journaling of messages in managed folders are controlled by managed content settings that are applied to the folder.
The range and depth of a search on a portal site, desktop or other.
The range and depth of a search on a portal site, desktop or other.
A unique manually created alpha-numeric label that is used to identify a product.
The value of a scorecard element in relation to the values of other elements of the same type.
A notification made up of a DSN code and a DSN message, that reports the result of an attempt to deliver an e-mail message.
To follow the flow of information; to monitor progress.
A feature that automatically corrects errors and makes other substitutions as soon as a user types text.
A system job that deletes selected records from one entity.
An icon in Windows Vista Control Panel that opens a dialog allowing user to change display options including screen resolution, refresh rate, color depth, and orientation.

A keyboard key that, when pressed in combination with another key, gives that key an alternative meaning, for example, producing an uppercase character when a letter key is pressed. The SHIFT key is also used in various key combinations to create nonstandard characters or to perform special operations.

A folder or file name longer than the 8.3 file name standard (up to eight characters followed by a period and an extension of up to three characters). Most versions of Windows, including WindowsXP, Windows2000, WindowNT, Windows95, and Windows98 support long file names up to 255 characters.
A condition in which paper is blocked in the printing path of a printer, scanner, photocopier or fax machine.
A type of expansion board on PC-compatible computers that allows the playback and recording of sound, such as from a WAV or MIDI file or a music CD-ROM. Most PCs sold at retail include a sound card.
A type of expansion board on PC-compatible computers that allows the playback and recording of sound, such as from a WAV or MIDI file or a music CD-ROM. Most PCs sold at retail include a sound card.
In telephony, the one-, two-, or three-character sequence that represents the country/region being called.
A feature in Windows that makes it possible to use characters that are not displayed on the keyboard.
To move selected items to another location for long term storage.
A diagram that is used to show hierarchical relationships; for example, company management and employee structures.
Any node within a tree, along with any selection of connected descendant nodes. In the registry structure, subtrees are the primary nodes that contain keys, subkeys, and value entries.

An area in a PivotTable or PivotChart report where you can drop fields from the Field List dialog box to display the data in the field. The labels on each drop area indicate the types of fields you can create in the report.
Pertaining to a value that indicates missing or unknown data.
Comments and tracked changes such as insertions, deletions, and formatting changes.

The ability of a thread to run in the security context of a security principal different from the security principal that started the process. This is usually so that a process can gain access to resources on behalf of a user.
A person who creates or maintains a weblog.
An area that shows available network connections and helps users quickly connect to the most appropriate one.
An Exchange Server feature that automatically places meetings marked Tentative on the recipient’s calendar without requiring the intervention of any client software such as Outlook.

All elements included in the Query window, such as tables, criteria, the order in which fields are arranged, and so on. The design also specifies whether Auto Query is turned on, and whether you can edit the source data.
The default tab on the ribbon interface that provides the basic features that users need most frequently for each application.
The replay of a digital media file.
A single compressed file containing a collection of files and folders that duplicate a Windows installation on a disk volume.
A collection of elements that can be treated as a whole.
An option in Call Timers that allows the user to clear the accumulated time displayed by the Recent Calls timer.
A format consisting of ASCII codes in which database, spreadsheet, and similar documents can be structured to facilitate their use by and transfer to other programs.
A control on a form or report used to display and manipulate OLE objects that are stored in tables.

Anti-spam functionality that is enabled on computers that have the Edge Transport server role installed to block messages according to characteristics of the sender. The Sender Reputation agent continuously monitors senders and their past Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) interactions, such as the amount of spam and messages that are not spam that a sender has sent, and relies on persisted data about the sender to determine what action, if any, to take on an inbound message.
A global template that you can use for any type of document. You can modify this template to change the default document formatting or content.
The set of records that results from running a query or applying a filter.
The set of records that results from running a query or applying a filter.
A message that is sent over a communications network such as a local area network or the Internet.
A message that is sent over a communications network such as a local area network or the Internet.

A message that is sent over a communications network such as a local area network or the Internet.

A Microsoft suite of modular, integrated applications and services that provide functionality for leads and opportunity management, customer history tracking and analysis, automated incident management, and business activity and employee performance forecasting and measurement.

An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines port-based network access control which either allows or denies connection requests to IEEE 802.3 wired Ethernet networks or IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.

An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines port-based network access control which either allows or denies connection requests to IEEE 802.3 wired Ethernet networks or IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.

An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines port-based network access control which either allows or denies connection requests to IEEE 802.3 wired Ethernet networks or IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.
The DNS name of a device on a network, used to locate computers on the network.
A feature that allows a user to share documents or applications with others. The user can also choose to give another person control of an application or the user's computer.
Pertaining to a disk to which content cannot be recorded.
The × character.
A file backup feature of Windows Vista that performs scheduled incremental backups of data to the target media. It also allows the user to restore an individual file or a group of files.
The uppermost directory on a computer, partition or volume.
The uppermost directory on a computer, partition or volume.
The uppermost directory on a computer, partition or volume.
A business in which any action taken on the main business can propagate to the subordinate business.
The protocol or protocols operating at a particular level within a protocol suite, such as IP within the TCP/IP suite.
A menu that shows only basic commands and commands that you use often.
The most trusted certification authority (CA), which is at the top of a certification hierarchy. The root CA has a self-signed certificate.
A diagram that is used to show relationships of elements to a core element.
A UI element that creates a user session or establishes user access to a service.
To show something.
For relationships that enforce referential integrity between tables, the updating of all related records in the related table or tables when a record in the primary table is changed.
A button-like control in the Ribbon that pops up a menu with more options when clicked.

A meeting participant who can do all sharing activities, including presenting, showing, sharing, and whiteboard, and admit participants from the lobby.

In some dialog boxes, the command button that is selected or highlighted when the dialog box is initially displayed. The default button has a bold border, indicating that it will be chosen automatically if you press ENTER. You can override a default button by clicking Cancel or another command button.
To revoke an action. To quit an action without saving any changes that the action would result in.
An area in a window or record that stores a single data value.
The specific description in a contract of the service support to be provided, including pricing and how support is to be allotted.
A tool in Windows Vista that backs up the entire computer (OS, settings, and files).
A statistical measure of the amount by which a set of values differs from the arithmetical mean, equal to the square root of the mean of the differences' squares.
A hyphen that is used to prevent a hyphenated word, number, or phrase from breaking if it falls at the end of a line.
The ( character.
A display utility that makes the computer screen more readable by people who have low vision by creating a separate window that displays a magnified portion of the screen.
An account, and its information, that is included within another account.
An Excel feature that automatically creates a sum formula based on user selection.
The key on the keyboard that is labeled with a right arrow.

A privilege on a computer system that allows a user to save, change, or delete stored data. Write access is usually set by the system administrator for a networked or server system and by the owner of the computer for a stand-alone machine.
The file that contains information about the files that have been imported into or captured in the current project, and how files or clips have been arranged.
A unique identifier that identifies a network node to other nodes on the network.
A method of translating images of printed text into machine-encoded text.
A method of translating images of printed text into machine-encoded text.
A system job that collects quality and performance information and sends it to Microsoft for analysis.
A marker that can be applied to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information. This allows the user to find, view and sort tagged items with ease.
A marker that can be applied to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information. This allows the user to find, view and sort tagged items with ease.
A telephone conversation between three or more people.
A telephone conversation between three or more people.
A key that, when pressed in combination with another key, gives the other key an alternative meaning.
A key that, when pressed in combination with another key, gives the other key an alternative meaning.
A key that, when pressed in combination with another key, gives the other key an alternative meaning.

A software implementation of a computer that emulates a complete hardware system, from processor to network card, in a self-contained, isolated software environment, enabling the simultaneous operation of otherwise incompatible operating systems.
The separator between account names and domain names in Internet e-mail addresses.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A color mixed with white. A 10-percent tint is one part of the original color and nine parts white.
A holding container for work items. Members of a queue must be of the same work item class (for example, only incidents).
A tool that allows the user to configure auto-replies.

A table configured on an Access Edge Server or Access Proxy containing the names and FQDNs (fully qualified domain names) of IM service providers, including public IM service providers, allowed to connect to that Access Edge Server or Access Proxy. These providers typically are responsible for routing to multiple domains.

descripGrp.descrip: The organization (the arrangement, size, and position) of the visual elements in your application, with respect to each other and the overall application window.
A fundamental unit of data structures which can be labeled and which can have data stored in it.
The area of the product in which you can work with business units, users, security roles, templates, subjects, services, and so on.
A decomposed layer of a full-color image used in printing. Typical printing processes use four color separations (cyan, magenta, yellow, and black) which combine together to produce the final image.
A type of query that, when you run it, prompts for values (criteria) to use to select the records for the result set so that the same query can be used to retrieve different result sets.
A field that contains the result of a query to an external data source.
An Address Book that contains entries for every group, user, and contact within an organization's implementation of Exchange Server.
An Address Book that contains entries for every group, user, and contact within an organization's implementation of Exchange Server.
An Address Book that contains entries for every group, user, and contact within an organization's implementation of Exchange Server.

A section of space on a physical disk that functions as if it were a separate disk.
A section of space on a physical disk that functions as if it were a separate disk.
A command-line tool that synchronizes data from an Active Directory forest to an Active Directory Application Mode (ADAM) instance.

Any information relating to a living individual who can be identified from that information. Such information may include name, country/region, street address, e-mail address, credit card number, social security number, government ID number, IP address, or any unique identifier that is associated with PII in another system.
A technology that enables the Exchange server to set a mobile device to erase all data the next time the device connects to the Exchange server.

descripGrp.descrip: A MAPI message that holds the delivery information for a message.
A MAPI message that holds the delivery information for a message.

A toolbar that is attached to one edge of the program window. When you drag a toolbar below the program title bar or to the left, right, or bottom edge of the window, the toolbar snaps into place on the edge of the program window.
A feature of Internet Explorer in Windows Vista that finds XML feeds on a webpage. User can view the feeds and subscribe to them.

One or more computers that have a connection to the Internet through an external screening router and a connection to the internal network through an interior screening router. Computers that are linked to the perimeter network have limited access to both the Internet and the internal network. This architecture is convenient if multiple hosts require direct Internet access.
A large-format publication, typically with one dimension much larger than the other, that is printed with a symbol, logo, slogan or other message.
A query that copies or changes data.
A language whose characters require ligation or shaping, such as a right-to-left language (Arabic, Persian, Hebrew, and Urdu) or certain South Asian languages.

Free time appears with a clear availability indicator and is seen as available when others view your Calendar. An appointment of zero duration, while visible in the selected block of time when viewing days, shows as free time to others.

A logical entity that enables a server to communicate with an iSCSI device over an Internet Protocol (IP) network. Each iSCSI initiator can have one or more network adapters through which communication is established.
A revenue objective specified as a monetary amount that has been assigned to a salesperson for a specified fiscal period.
A communication line used for data transfer among the components of a computer system.
To split a message for routing purposes to deliver to multiple recipients.
A presentation within a presentation in which you group slides in an existing presentation so that you can show that section of the presentation to a particular audience.
The ability to connect to public IM service providers.

descripGrp.descrip: The distance between characters in a line of text. Tracking, kerning, and scaling can be used to adjust the space between characters.

In Windows-based computers, a 32-bit value (a bitmask) that specifies the permissions that are assigned in an access control entry (ACE). An access mask is also part of the access request when an object is opened. The access mask in the request is compared to the access mask in each ACE to determine whether or not to grant the request.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A set of characters added to the end of a file name that identifies the file type or format.
A set of characters added to the end of a file name that identifies the file type or format.

A component of Exchange transport that processes all incoming messages and determines what to do with the messages based on information about the intended recipients. In Exchange Server 2007, the Edge Transport server uses the categorizer to route the message to the appropriate destination. The Hub Transport server uses the categorizer to expand distribution lists and identify alternate recipients and forwarding addresses. After the categorizer retrieves full information about recipients, it uses that information to apply policies, route the message, and perform content conversion.
In Exchange Server 2007, a function that is used as a condition or exception on a transport rule to determine whether an action should be applied to an e-mail message.
A logical structure that organizes the members of a set into parent-child relationships.
A set of songs and/or albums selected by the customer, from the customer's music library. ​
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.

A product key that is provided to Microsoft customers who choose a Microsoft Volume Licensing program for their organizations and that allows multiple installations of a particular product. The key is assigned to a company or institution intended for their sole use and only for distribution to employees or third parties who are authorized to install and distribute licenses pursuant to the terms of their license agreement.

The key is assigned to a company or institution intended for their sole use and only for distribution to employees or third parties who are authorized to install and distribute licenses pursuant to the terms of their license agreement.

descripGrp.descrip: A dialog that requires the user to take some action before the focus can switch to another form or dialog box. Dialog boxes and messages are usually modal.
To submit an article in a newsgroup or other online conference or forum. The term is derived from the "posting" of a notice on a physical bulletin board.
A value that is automatically used by a program when the user does not specify an alternative. Defaults are built into a program when a value or option must be assumed for the program to function.
Text that alerts a user to a note or a warning.
To acknowledge an action or the value of some data (e.g. password) by definite assurance.
A handle that supports sizing an object.
One or more special characters used to separate peers in a delimited structure, at any level (fields, records, and so on).

A storage platform that provides a single repository for managing multiple types of unstructured information in one infrastructure. The Exchange store combines the features and functionality of the file system, the Web, and a collaboration server (such as Microsoft Exchange) through a single, URL-addressable location for storing, accessing, and managing information, as well as building and running applications. The Exchange store is also known as the Web Storage System.
A button in a video conversation window that starts or restarts the video feed.
A descriptive or user-friendly label for a control or object, displayed on the screen. The display name may differ from the internal name.
A modeless secondary window that displays a toolbar or other choices, such as colors or patterns.
A set of slides that are imported or created for display in a meeting.

A website from Microsoft which provides updates (patches and fixes) for multiple Microsoft products in one place, including Windows operating system software and Windows-based hardware, Microsoft Office system, Microsoft SQL Server, and Microsoft Exchange Server.

A website from Microsoft which provides updates (patches and fixes) for multiple Microsoft products in one place, including Windows operating system software and Windows-based hardware, Microsoft Office system, Microsoft SQL Server, and Microsoft Exchange Server.
A security access level that allows a user access to record types in the user's business unit and all business units subordinate to the user's business unit.
A standard set of formats and procedures that enable computers to exchange information.
A keyboard key that is used in conjunction with another key to produce some special feature or function and is typically marked with the letters Alt.

The smallest unit of information handled by a computer or device. One bit expresses a 1 or a 0 in a binary numeral, or a true or false logical condition. A group of 8 bits makes up a byte, which can represent many types of information, such as a letter of the alphabet, a decimal digit, or other character.

The smallest unit of information handled by a computer or device. One bit expresses a 1 or a 0 in a binary numeral, or a true or false logical condition. A group of 8 bits makes up a byte, which can represent many types of information, such as a letter of the alphabet, a decimal digit, or other character.
A managed software component that monitors events and performance pertaining to a specific application component, and transmits observations to a host application for display, action, or reporting.

An integral Windows component that supports building, deploying, and running the next generation of applications and XML Web services. It provides a highly productive, standards-based, multilanguage environment for integrating existing investments with next generation applications and services, as well as the agility to solve the challenges of deployment and operation of Internet-scale applications. The .NET Framework consists of three main parts: the common language runtime, a hierarchical set of unified class libraries, and a componentized version of ASP called ASP.NET.
A measurement used for high-capacity data storage. One terabyte equals 240, or 1,099,511,627,776, bytes, although it is commonly interpreted as simply one trillion bytes.
A measurement used for high-capacity data storage. One terabyte equals 240, or 1,099,511,627,776, bytes, although it is commonly interpreted as simply one trillion bytes.
A keyboard key that, when pressed (and held), changes the actions of ordinary input.
To transfer a copy of a file from a remote device to a requesting device by means of a modem or network.
A technology that uses multidimensional structures to provide rapid access to data for analysis. The source data for OLAP is commonly stored in data warehouses in a relational database.
A technology that uses multidimensional structures to provide rapid access to data for analysis. The source data for OLAP is commonly stored in data warehouses in a relational database.

A slide view or page on which you define formatting for all slides or pages in your presentation. Each presentation has a master for each key component: slides, title slides, speaker's notes, and audience handouts.
A feature that allows various mathematical symbols to be entered using the keyboard.
A reusable piece of content, formatting information or other document parts that are stored in galleries.
A concrete implementation of one or more COM interfaces. COM objects are instances of COM classes.
An implementation of the Internet Message Format defined by RFC2822. A message item is stored in the Exchange store.
An alert that is shown to prompt the user to agree to the action being taken.
A visual output device aimed at displaying various type of information.
To adjust precisely for a particular function.
A feature that provides Web-based applications in a central location to help businesses manage sales, customer relationships, projects, employees, and company functions.
To make a chart sheet or worksheet the active, or selected, sheet. The sheet that you activate determines which menu bar and toolbars are displayed.
An external bus that supports Plug and Play installation, which enables you to connect and disconnect devices without shutting down or restarting your computer.
An external bus that supports Plug and Play installation, which enables you to connect and disconnect devices without shutting down or restarting your computer.
A Windows wizard that helps the user import digital video to the computer from digital video cameras and other sources.

The number of colors or levels of gray that can be displayed at one time. The amount or memory in the computer's graphics controller card controls the display. An 8-bit controller can display 256 colors or levels of gray; a 16-bit controller, 64,000 colors; and a 24-bit controller, 16.8 million colors.

A power-saving state that allows the computer or device to quickly resume full-power operation (typically within several seconds) when you want to start working again. All open documents and programs are saved to memory before the computer or device enters the low-power state.

A power-saving state that allows the computer or device to quickly resume full-power operation (typically within several seconds) when you want to start working again. All open documents and programs are saved to memory before the computer or device enters the low-power state.
A record, such as a contact, that you designate as subordinate to a master record.
A sequence of activities, actions, or tasks through which documents or items are passed as part of an automated business process.
A method of payment by which a customer pays the freight carrier for goods when they are delivered. The freight carrier then remits the payment to the shipper.
A method of payment by which a customer pays the freight carrier for goods when they are delivered. The freight carrier then remits the payment to the shipper.
A special memory subsystem in which frequently used data values are duplicated for quick access.
A list of tasks that appears in the Tasks folder and in the TaskPad in Calendar.

A 9-digit number used to identify an entity (company or person) for tax reporting purposes in the U.S. There are several different types of tax identification numbers, such as employer identification number (EIN), Social Security number (SSN), individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN), and adopted taxpayer identification number (ATIN).
A word with the same meaning as another in the same language but often with different implications and associations.
To verify, test or control by comparison or examination.

The process an operating system uses to detect and record security-related events, such as an attempt to create, to access, or to delete objects such as files and directories. The records of such events are stored in a file known as a security log, whose contents are available only to those with the proper clearance.
Pertaining to a mixture of characters that are read from left to right and characters that are read from right to left.
Pertaining to a mixture of characters that are read from left to right and characters that are read from right to left.
The protocol within TCP/IP that governs the breakup of data messages into packets to be sent via IP, and the reassembly and verification of the complete messages from packets received by IP.
The protocol within TCP/IP that governs the breakup of data messages into packets to be sent via IP, and the reassembly and verification of the complete messages from packets received by IP.

The file that a linked or embedded object is inserted into, or that data is saved to. The source file contains the information that is used to create the object. When you change information in a destination file, the information is not updated in the source file.

A database repository for information about a computer's configuration. The registry contains information that Windows continually references during operation, such as: profiles for each user; the programs installed on the computer and the types of documents that each can create; property settings for folders and program icons; what hardware exists on the system; which ports are being used. The registry is organized hierarchically as a tree, and it is made up of keys and their subkeys, hives, and entries.
A logical 'else' statement in a workflow that defines an alternative action in all cases that do not match the criteria defined in condition or branch elements.
A folder that stores the user's music library.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
To join or link.
The state of an expression or a variable (for example, when a result can be either true or false, or equal or not equal).
A World Wide Web version of Windows Client Help.
A World Wide Web version of Windows Client Help.
The « character.
A template that serves exclusively as the basis for creating other workflows. Workflow templates cannot start workflow jobs.
The element in an XML document that contains all other elements. It is the top-level element of an XML document and must be the first element in the document.
The element in an XML document that contains all other elements. It is the top-level element of an XML document and must be the first element in the document.

A method used with SCSI and IDE disk drives to translate the cylinder, head, and sector specifications of the drive into addresses that can be used by an enhanced BIOS. LBA is used with drives that are larger than 528MB.

A method used with SCSI and IDE disk drives to translate the cylinder, head, and sector specifications of the drive into addresses that can be used by an enhanced BIOS. LBA is used with drives that are larger than 528MB.
One of two types of hardware that are connected by an RS-232-C serial connection, the other being a Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) device.
One of two types of hardware that are connected by an RS-232-C serial connection, the other being a Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) device.
The name of a category of information in a mail-merge data source. For example, "City," "State," and "PostalCode" are commonly used field names in an address list.
In programming, a value that is given to a variable, either at the beginning of an operation or before an expression is evaluated by a program.
Pertaining to an entire document, file, or program rather than to a restricted segment of it.
Imported from an accounting system. Refers to the product or service item list that was imported from the accounting system into Business Contact Manager for Outlook.

A method of delivering digital media across a network in a continuous flow. The digital media is played by client software as it is received. Typically, streaming makes it unnecessary for users to download a file before playing it.

termGrp.term: transmisión en secuencia de contido multimedia

descripGrp.descrip: A service that allows a customer to view and manage account and billing information for Microsoft services online.
A high-speed Internet connection. Broadband connections are typically 256 kilobytes per second (KBps) or faster. Broadband includes DSL and cable modem service.
A measure of the fineness of detail in an image or text, usually as produced by a monitor or printer.
To move data from one location to another.
A situation in which one object refers back to itself, either directly or indirectly.
The “ character.
The “ character.

To put back into a stable condition. A computer user may be able to recover lost or damaged data by using a program to search for and salvage whatever information remains in storage. A database may be recovered by restoring its integrity after some problem has damaged it, such as abnormal termination of the database management program.
A semiconductor circuit that contains information that cannot be modified.
A semiconductor circuit that contains information that cannot be modified.
A division between window panes in a split window; the split bar visually separates window panes.
A value or condition that is not consistent with the true, specified, or expected value or condition.
Software that changes browser settings, such as the home page, without adequate consent.
A standard Windows control that combines the characteristics of a text box with a drop-down list box.
The slide that stores information about the design template applied, including font styles, placeholder sizes and positions, background design, and color schemes.

The core of layered architecture that manages the most basic operations of the operating system and the computer's processor. The kernel schedules different blocks of executing code, called threads, for the processor to keep it as busy as possible and coordinates multiple processors to optimize performance. The kernel also synchronizes activities among Executive-level subcomponents, such as I/O Manager and Process Manager, and handles hardware exceptions and other hardware-dependent functions. The kernel works closely with the hardware abstraction layer.
The format of a file, commonly indicated by its file name extension. The file type indicates which program the file was created in and can be opened with.
A Windows feature that allows users to connect remotely to a computer and access programs, files, and network resources as though they were sitting at the computer.
A view of the workspace that displays the sequence of your clips.
A structured document or template with spaces reserved for entering information and often containing special coding (e.g. to trigger data processing).
The * character. Indicates multiplication in programming languages and also serves as a wildcard character representing one or more characters.
A feature that allows you to send a snapshot of your calendar to someone outside your Exchange organization and allow them to see the data on your calendar and schedule against it.
In a conversation window, this is the list of people who are currently participating in the conversation.
A group of OneNote sections.
The arrangement of text and graphics on the page of a document.
A search method that lets you direct your search using conversational language.
A search method that lets you direct your search using conversational language.

The protocol that improves the security of data communication by using a combination of data encryption, digital certificates, and public key cryptography. SSL enables authentication and increases data integrity and privacy over networks. SSL does not provide authorization or nonrepudiation.

The protocol that improves the security of data communication by using a combination of data encryption, digital certificates, and public key cryptography. SSL enables authentication and increases data integrity and privacy over networks. SSL does not provide authorization or nonrepudiation.

To add a special visual or sound effect to text or an object. For example, you can have your text bullet points fly in from the left, one word at a time, or hear the sound of applause when a picture is uncovered.
In replication, a database instance that receives replicated data.
In replication, a database instance that receives replicated data.
A connection that specifies the name, type, location, and, optionally, other information about a database file or server.
A combination of any of the character formatting options identified by a style name.
The " character.

The process of finalizing a purchase on a website. For example, when customers shop on your website, they may select several items and save them in their shopping basket. When they have finished shopping, they click on a checkout link or graphical button that takes them to an online form where they enter their name, billing address, payment type, and shipping information.

A menu that contains commands you can use to manipulate a window or close a program. You click the program icon at the left of the title bar to open this menu. The context menu of a window replaces this menu.
In information processing, fixed or predetermined. For example, a static memory buffer remains invariant in size throughout program execution.
A graphic representation of trends in data series, such as a line sloping upward to represent increased sales over a period of months.

The underlying or original style on which other styles in a document are dependent. When you change a formatting element of the base style in a document, all other styles that originate from the base style will also reflect the change.
To carry on a real-time conversation with other users by computer or device.
Ready-made art, often appearing as a bitmap or a combination of drawn shapes.
The listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
The listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
The listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
Help that is available to the user while not being connected to or part of a system or network.

A menu for a group of ready-made shapes that includes basic shapes, such as rectangles and circles, plus a variety of lines and connectors, block arrows, flowchart symbols, stars and banners, and callouts.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed sequentially.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed sequentially.

To move a document or other data in a window in order to view a particular portion of the document. Scrolling may be controlled by the mouse, arrow keys, or other keys on the keyboard, eventually with one or more fingers.

A Windows program that collects and displays for users the system-level features of the computer, including hardware and software setup and configuration. From Control Panel, users can click individual items to configure system-level features and perform related tasks.
An item on the user's My Status menu that the user can select to notify other users that he or she does not want to be interrupted.
A software that was installed on the system without user's consent.
A standard control that allows a user to select from a fixed set of mutually exclusive choices.
A standard control that allows a user to select from a fixed set of mutually exclusive choices.
The speed at which a modem can transmit data, measured by the number of events, or signal changes, that occur in one second.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of communications that take place without the use of interconnecting wires or cables, such as by radio, microwave, or infrared.
Any text string used as a label, such as the name of a procedure or a variable in a program or the name attached to a hard disk or floppy disk.
To move around in a document.
In reference to a computing device or a program, unable to communicate with a primary database or controlling computer.
A commonly used file format for storing contact information. Contacts that use the vCard format are stored as .vcf files.
A series of contiguous processing steps through which one or more messages flow.
A collection of photos in electronic format that have been grouped into a virtual album.

An ad that is served to a user's screen either as a pushed (sent by e-mail) or pulled ad (requested by a user's browser). This includes measurement of responses from an ad delivery system to a user's browser.
An entity entrusted to issue certificates that assert that the recipient individual, computer, or organization requesting the certificate fulfills the conditions of an established policy.
An entity entrusted to issue certificates that assert that the recipient individual, computer, or organization requesting the certificate fulfills the conditions of an established policy.
A feature that automatically adjusts the layout if you insert items that don't fit the original layout. You can undo it using the Automatic Layout Options button.
Pertaining to the state of an object when it is not the focus of a user's input.
An industry-standard one-way, 128-bit hashing scheme, developed by RSA Data Security, Inc., and used by various Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) vendors for encrypted authentication.
An attribute of the Address entity used to identify an address. It is a required field on the Address form.
The cells that you copy when you want to paste data into another location. After you copy cells, a moving border appears around them to indicate that they've been copied.
A number specifying a location in memory where data is stored.
To transfer a file from one location to another. After the file is transferred, there is only one copy of the file, in the new location.
A disk, file, document, or other collection of information from which data is taken or moved.
A disk, file, document, or other collection of information from which data is taken or moved.

A device that reads the information stored on a compact disc. A compact disc player contains the optical equipment necessary for reading a disc's contents and the electronic circuitry for interpreting the data as it is read.

A device that reads the information stored on a compact disc. A compact disc player contains the optical equipment necessary for reading a disc's contents and the electronic circuitry for interpreting the data as it is read.
An e-mail feature providing feedback to the sender that a message has been read by the recipient.
A system job that parses a file used in data migration or import.
The amount of memory physically installed on your device (as opposed to on a storage card.)
In object-oriented programming, a reusable basic design structure, consisting of abstract and concrete classes, that assists in building applications.
To reduce the amount of information displayed by hiding from view the subentries within a folder, section or conversation, or a portion of text or other content within a control.
A unit of application logic providing data and services to other applications that can invoke Web protocols.
Instructions that make hardware work.
A window or menu that presents an array or grid of visual choices to a user for selection.

A group of characters or character bytes handled as a single entity. Computer programs use strings to store and transmit data and commands. Most programming languages consider strings (such as 2674:gstmn) as distinct from numeric values (such as 470924).
An infotip for the button on the phone and video controls that ends the conversation.

A connection between multiple tables where records from related fields that match are combined and shown as one record. Records that don't match may be included or excluded, depending on the type of join.
Done by positioning the pointer over an item and pressing the left mouse button once.
A user who creates or edits a document.
A sign or symbol that specifies the type of calculation to perform within an expression. There are mathematical, comparison, logical, and reference operators.
To configure settings to restrict access to or permissions for a file or specific elements within a file.
A program, routine, or process that performs a specific system function to support other programs.

The degree of difference between light and dark extremes of color on a monitor, device screen, or printed output, or between the darkest and lightest areas in a photo. The greater the difference, the higher the contrast.
A collection of users, computers, contacts, and other groups that is used only for e-mail distribution, and addressed as a single recipient.
A collection of users, computers, contacts, and other groups that is used only for e-mail distribution, and addressed as a single recipient.
A collection of users, computers, contacts, and other groups that is used only for e-mail distribution, and addressed as a single recipient.
The procedures involved in preparing a software program or application to operate within a computer or mobile device.
An element of workflow logic that defines an alternative wait condition with a corresponding set of additional steps that are only performed when the initial criterion is met.
A wizard that guides the user through installing a printer on their network.

termGrp.term: Asistente de instalación de impresoras de rede

descripGrp.descrip: The name given by an administrator to a collection of networked computers that share a common directory. Part of the DNS naming structure, domain names consist of a sequence of name labels separated by periods.
The only member of the replica set in which you can make changes to the database structure that can be propagated to other replicas.
A physical card that represents a specific value or amount of service for which the user has paid in advance.
A folder on another computer that has been made available for other people to use on the network.
A smart card that stores a subscriber's personal identifier, billing information, and data.
A smart card that stores a subscriber's personal identifier, billing information, and data.
A company that provides telephone and other communications services to consumers.
A company that provides telephone and other communications services to consumers.
A Movie Maker tool that helps users quickly create a movie by analyzing the video, pictures, and music that a user selects, and then combining those to create a movie.
An object that enables user interaction or input, often to initiate an action, display information, or set values.

A link to any item accessible on your computer or on a network, such as a program or application, file, folder, disk drive, printer, or another computer. You can put shortcuts in various areas, such as on the desktop, on the Start menu, or in specific folders.
A location or selection of text in a file that you name for reference purposes. Bookmarks identify a location within your file that you can later refer or link to.
A location or selection of text in a file that you name for reference purposes. Bookmarks identify a location within your file that you can later refer or link to.
A letter that serves to introduce accompanying documents to the recipient. Often refers to a letter sent with a resume when applying for a job.
A feature in Windows that uses add-in programs, or gadgets, to extend information from your computer onto secondary displays.
