The process of creating and sending text messages between or to mobile phones and devices using the SMS protocol.

Any hardware or software that can detect events or environmental changes, such as your current location or the amount of light around your computer. For example, a notebook with a location sensor, such as a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver, can determine your exact location. An ambient light sensor can detect when there is a change in lighting, and then a program can use that information to adjust the brightness of your screen.

A device that includes an antenna, a radio receiver, and a processor for use with the worldwide GPS (Global Positioning System). A GPS receiver uses position and time information from four GPS satellites to calculate precise information about its current location, its speed of travel, and the current time.
A category of sensor that can detect the current location of your computer.

Technologies that measure and analyze physical and behavioral human characteristics, such as fingerprints, eye retinas and irises, voice patterns, facial patterns, hand measurements, typing patterns and signatures, to recognize or authenticate identity.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that provides support for sensors such as enabling, disabling or uninstalling sensors and sensor-enabled applications, changing sensor settings, etc.
A type of light sensor that tracks ambient light in the surroundings and therefore the amount of backlight needed for the LCD screen to be adjusted accordingly.

A package of market-specific content delivered in Windows for 20 target markets. A Local Pack contains market-customized themes (wallpapers, sound schemes, etc.) and locally flavored Internet Explorer favorites and RSS feeds.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that allows the user to designate his home coordinates or address for location-aware functionalities.
An arrangement of search results ordered by relevance using a special search algorithm.

A framework that provides a single point for IT professionals and OEMs to service and maintain Windows images offline through a scriptable command line utility and an easily extensible infrastructure.
A gadget that users can display on their desktop, rather than on the Windows Sidebar. Examples are clocks, news headlines, slide shows, and weather forecasts.
Automatic display adjustment that changes the brightness of your PC screen (laptop and desktop) using light environment information provided by the ambient light sensor.

A radio navigation system developed by the U.S. Department of Defense that uses a constellation of 24 earth satellites, which are monitored by ground-based control stations, to provide precise, continuous worldwide positioning and timing information.
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, e-mail address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, e-mail address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
A provider of online services like e-mail, messaging, and others (example: Windows Live, Yahoo, Google).
The process of maintaining connectivity outside of one's usual service or coverage area.
A connection that enables the transmission of data.
A call that originates from your mobile device.
A collaborative action, such as sharing, calendar sharing, or using a whiteboard.
An item on the user's Status menu. A user can select this status to indicate that they are not actively using their computer.
E-mail that a customer does not want delivered to their inbox, including spam and phishing messages (identified by the mail service) and messages from blocked senders and domains.
E-mail that a customer does not want delivered to their inbox, including spam and phishing messages (identified by the mail service) and messages from blocked senders and domains.

A set of colors and background images that lets users change the appearance of Windows Live pages. The theme is common to all pages, except for group, event, and space pages, which may each have their own theme.
Parental consent for a child to use a Windows Live service, view a website, or communicate with a person.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show nonsequential information.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show steps in a process or timeline.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a continual process.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show how parts relate to a whole.

The descriptive information about a user that is shown to other users. This editable information is separate from the registration information they provide to establish their Windows Live account. This separation allows users to disclose or conceal personal information as they choose.
An answer that only the user knows for a specific question. The answer is used to confirm someone's identity if they forget their password.

A horizontal grouping of actions that apply to the container (or containers) with which the toolbar is associated. For example, a container in which mail is viewed might have an action toolbar with options that include Reply, Delete, and Move to.
The user role that is assigned to a user account, which determines the options that are visible to that user and the tasks that the user can perform in the management interface for Exchange Labs.
The user role that is assigned to a user account, which determines the options that are visible to that user and the tasks that the user can perform in the management interface for Exchange Labs.

termGrp.term: función de control de acceso baseado en funcións

descripGrp.descrip: The user role that is assigned to a user account, which determines the options that are visible to that user and the tasks that the user can perform in the management interface for Exchange Labs.
A service that enables customers to implement Windows Live communication services within their own personal domains.
A disk image provided for use in repairing or reinstalling an installation of Windows.
The person whom, or place that, a caller is calling.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
An extension of the conventional touch input feature to allow multiple fingers touching the computer or device screen at the same time.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving around a center point or one finger moving around a finger that is not moving.
An engine that specifically recognizes and processes touch input and multi-touch input as commands.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
A collection of computing resources such as programs and virtual desktops that enable a user to accomplish a set of related tasks.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the user’s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
Silent and unexpected process termination by the process itself or by another application.
To shut down a core processor for power saving purpose.
To reopen a core processor that had been parked for power saving purpose.
A feature of Windows Media Player that allows users to remove gaps between tracks that they burn to audio CDs.
Existing in reference to the removal of silences or clicks between tracks when they are burnt to an audio CD or when they are played back from the CD.
A unique identifier made from four otherwise separate pieces of information. For example, a color can be specified by a black, yellow, magenta and cyan quad.
Any information (e.g. account numbers, sensitive data, etc.) with a title and some free-form text that can be stored in a secure manner in a personal vault.
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
A feature that replicates the animation associated with a source object to one or more target objects.
An abstract grouping of similar animation effects.
An effect that a user can apply to an image to achieve a specific artistic look.
A visual representation of an audio signal over time.
An image editing feature that allows a user to isolate the foreground portion of an image and make the background transparent.
An option that removes narrations and laser pointer gestures or timings from a presentation or from a specific slide.
The process of adding geospatial metadata (e.g. longitude, latitude) to media (e.g. Websites, RSS feeds, or images).
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
To remove a file from the Microsoft Office Document Cache without deleting it on the server.
A security feature that validates files before allowing them to be loaded by the application, in order to protect against file format vulnerabilities.
A feature that allows end users and IT admins to control which file types and versions can be opened and saved in the application.

A feature that allows the user to superimpose a dot over a presentation and control its position with the mouse. The appearance of the dot is similar to that of a traditional laser pointer, and it is broadcast to all presentation viewers and can be recorded into video (Save to Video).
An option that initiates an e-mail response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
An option that initiates an e-mail response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which displays full-screen slide shows for photos.
A recordable media (such as CD-RW) to which you can only write once without reformatting.
A recordable media to which you can write several times without reformatting.
A feature that is added to the Microsoft Office Compatibility Pack to open Word, Excel, and PowerPoint binary format files and securely convert them to the Office 2007 file formats.
A feature that makes Outlook auto-complete lists available through the default Exchange mailbox.

A common credential store and interface that is used to save and manage user credentials, such as user names and passwords, so you can easily log on to Web sites and connect to other resources, such as computers.
A set of credentials that users can create, store and manage in Credential Manager.
A type of vault that contains Web passwords and secure notes that you can place on a USB flash drive and use on another computer.

To remove data permanently from a storage medium. This is usually done by replacing existing data with zeros or meaningless text or, in magnetic media, by disturbing the magnetic particles' physical arrangement, either with the erase head or with a large magnet.
A note that contains recorded information.

A feature that enables presenters in the rich client to broadcast a slide show to remote viewers watching in a Web browser. Throughout the presentation, the remote attendees will see the current slide being shown by the presenter.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A feature that allows the user to insert the contents of an open window or a screen clipping into the current document without the need to utilize external applications.
A central hub for viewing pending uploads to http servers (mainly SharePoint) and correcting upload errors.
A central hub for viewing pending uploads to http servers (mainly SharePoint) and correcting upload errors.
A central hub for viewing pending uploads to http servers (mainly SharePoint) and correcting upload errors.
A feature that makes automatic versions of user documents during each autosave operation and allows the user to revert to previous copies of the document with ease.
A feature that alerts users to potential issues with e-mail recipients before the message is sent.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
To make a single file out of a set of files using a program such as compress, gzip, or PKZIP.
A feature that displays a definition or translation of a word or piece of text in a ScreenTip when the pointer is moved over the selection.
Instant messaging with federated contacts.
Instant messaging with federated contacts.
An instant message with a federated contact.
An instant message with a federated contact.
Instant messaging with internal users.
Instant messaging with internal users.
Pertaining to federated instant messaging.
Pertaining to federated instant messaging.
A radio network that provides coverage for cellular telephone communications.

To copy driver binaries, install services, and add registry keys for one or more drivers from a driver package onto a system, without the context of a specific device. A system can be booted from reflected drivers, however full device installation may still be required in order to enable full driver functionality.
A Windows feature that enables users to share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers with other people on a home network.
An abstract grouping of similar transition effects.
A digital distribution provider of games such as MSN Games, Yahoo Games, Steam, Stardock, GameTap, and so on.
A file used as part of a testing process to check the validity or correctness of a program or procedure.
A feature that helps users of some Office applications to improve the accessibility of documents they create.
An instant message that is transmitted while the sender or recipient is offline.

termGrp.term: mensaxe instantánea en modo sen conexión

descripGrp.descrip: The helper program that can store sign-in information for multiple Windows Live IDs.

termGrp.term: Asistente de inicio de sesión en Windows Live

descripGrp.descrip: A feature that offers improved security by loading a document in a read-only view, rather than in the full editor, for scenarios that pose a greater potential security risk.
A package containing everything you need to show one or many PowerPoint presentations on another computer. This package can be saved to a folder or burned to a CD.

A feature that allows the user to indicate that a document is trusted, and therefore can be opened without security notifications, so long as the filepath and creation time of the document remain unchanged.
A list that displays someone's recent activity on Windows Live.
The contact picture label that indicates someone has been invited to do something, but has not responded yet.
The link to the webpage where a user manages photos and albums.
The link to the main landing/start page on Windows Live.
The process of establishing a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A Windows library that allows users to store, manage and share all their recorded TV items.
A Windows service that provides software licensing activation and notification.
An extensible platform component for decoding/encoding digital images and performing common transforms.
A Windows feature that provides a direct connection to a corporate network for people working outside of the office. It is a superior alternative to VPN.
A PC (desktop and beyond) search platform that allows search of the local hard drive plus network locations like SharePoint sites and the Internet.
A set of attributes that define a user's access to a given service or application.
To break a connection.
To call the last person called from a phone or device.
To send text messages from a mobile phone or device.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to compare or show the relationship between two ideas. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to text at the top of one side of the center point. Emphasizes Level 2 text, which is limited to four shapes on each side of the center point. The balance tips towards the side with the most shapes containing Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps or tasks that depict a plan or result. The last Level 1 line of text appears after the equals sign (=).Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information of equal value. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the top shape and its Level 2 text is used for the subsequent lists.
The process of customizing the look and feel of a product to support marketing or promotion of another company.

Not able to be delivered to an intended recipient. If an e-mail message is undeliverable, it is returned to the sender with information added by the mail server explaining the problem; for example, the e-mail address may be incorrect, or the recipient's mailbox may be full.
To reject or turn off a system notification such as a reminder, a new message alert or an alarm.
A telephone call the user has failed to answer.
As set of rules defined by the administrator. For example, the policy may require all users to change their passwords.
A company that provides services or content for its customers.
The act of sending the current phone call to a third person.
A menu item that transfers the current phone call without the user remaining on the line to announce the call.
A Windows Phone application that is both a digital still camera and a digital video camera.
An occurrence, activity or happening of significance that occurs.
The on-screen representation of the phone keypad or dial pad on the device.
The mechanical part that makes the phone ring to indicate an incoming call.
A type of personal identification number (PIN) for the SIM card, consisting of 4 digits, that is used to gain access to your mobile phone.

A piece of hardware that supports multiple discrete capabilities, such as audio, mixer, and music, on a single card. This device is sometimes treated as a bus that can be enumerated to locate the devices on that bus.
To expose a virtual disk to the user, backed by a file.

The administrative task of making remote resources available to its users, setting policies that control how users will connect, how they will find the remote resources, and what settings users will connect with.
A feature that provides an interface for acquiring rich metadata in order to support showing device detail information in the Device Center and the Device Stage.
A .cab file that can only have one locale support and that provides all the hardware display components in order for your device information to be shown in the Control Panel.
A .cab file that can only have one locale support and that provides all the hardware display components in order for your device information to be shown in the Control Panel.
To uninstall all software on a computer and reinstall a new Windows image.
An easy-to-use troubleshooter that helps find and fix program compatibility issues.

termGrp.term: solucionador de problemas de compatibilidade de programas

descripGrp.descrip: A small pop-up window that informs users of a non-critical problem or special condition in a control.
A category of sensor that collects biometric data for a variety of applications.
A category of sensor that may use all or some of the following applied stimulus to detect movement: ultrasound, infrared, heat and vibration.
A biometric sensor that analyses your eye retina to recognize or authenticate identity.
A category of sensor that can respond to an applied stimulus by generating an electrical signal.
A category of sensor that is used for mechanical measurement of force, scale, pressure, strain, etc.
A category of sensor that tracks environmental changes such as temperature, atmospheric pressure, humidity, wind speed and wind direction.
A type of sensor that can determine without physical contact if an object/person is nearby, or can be used to measure the distance between the object/person and the sensor device.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.
A category of sensor that responds to a pre-defined amount of light.
An Internet site that provides a collection of products and services developed by Microsoft partners for Microsoft Office users.
To remove a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A view mode in Internet Explorer that determines whether content is rendered as if users were viewing it in a previous version of Internet Explorer.
The physical material, such as paper, disk, and tape, used for storing computer-based information.
An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 802.11 wireless network in which Service Set Identifier (SSID) suppression is enabled.

A feature that prevents Internet Explorer from storing data about your browsing session. This helps prevent anyone else who might be using your computer from seeing where you visited and what you looked at on the Web.
The feature that blocks third-party web content that could potentially track someone's web activity.

A form of IIS authentication in which IIS accepts client-certificates used to prove the client's identity. Using this form of authentication, IIS can optionally map a client certificate to a Windows user account by using an internal mapping table or Active Directory.

A command prompt that is run in a privileged administrator security context that allows actions that would normally be restricted. Without elevation, command prompts in Windows Client and Windows Server run in a restricted state.

termGrp.term: símbolo do sistema con privilexios elevados

descripGrp.descrip: The link group that includes links to the About Hotmail webpage, the What's New webpage, and so on.
The Windows Live service for event planning and invitations.

The link that appears above an incomplete content set and leads to the full list of items. For example, when a content module displays items 1–6, a "View all" link in line with the module label leads to a webpage that lists all items. The items that are available in preview are redundantly available in the list of all items, which may be paginated.
A contribution or feedback left by someone viewing content on a site. Someone who views a space, photos, or files can leave a comment, if permissions allow it.
A computer that belongs to a homegroup.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems with viewing computers or shared files in a homegroup.

termGrp.term: solucionador de problemas de Grupo doméstico

descripGrp.descrip: To group together multiple windows of the same application under a single button on the taskbar’s taskband.
A feature that allows the user to digitally alter a picture to increase or decrease the sharpness of focus.
An organizer used to add, uninstall, and search for desktop gadgets.
A program that helps make the text on your screen easier to read for long periods of time.
A virtual device created by System Restore that is needed to set a system restore point.
A zoom out gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving towards the other finger at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom out gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving towards the other finger at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A software or device that helps control your home smart devices automatically.

termGrp.term: controlador de automatización de dispositivos domésticos

descripGrp.descrip: An input device used chiefly for identification purposes that reads information that has been magnetically encoded, usually in two tracks, on a plastic card, such as a credit card or an employee badge.
A notebook that is smaller in size and lighter in weight than a full-sized notebook, while retaining the same functionality.
A gallery containing thumbnail views of open application windows.
A primary storage device based on solid-state memory, such as flash memory, that provides nonvolatile storage with benefits of performance, reliability and power saving.
A node that makes cached data available to clients needing to retrieve the data.
To apply a marker to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information.
An authoritative source for an attribute value that can flow its value to other destination directories and systems.

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).
A method of blocking access to websites based on their content. For example, In Windows Live Family Safety, parents can specify a filtering level, such as Strict or Basic, for their child.
A person authorized to manage and make certain changes to a group, such as to approve a membership request.
An audio or video file that you rent from an online store, typically for a monthly fee.
A troubleshooter that performs common maintenance tasks in Windows, such as cleaning up unused files and shortcuts.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems about hardware and devices.

termGrp.term: solucionador de problemas de hardware e dispositivos

descripGrp.descrip: A search location exposed via .osdx templates and made possible via the OpenSearch technology. It connects the local search indexer to a remote index and provides the end user with the ability to search for files on a Web site or on an intranet site from within Windows.
A Web site from Microsoft which provides solutions for the top issues about Windows Update or Microsoft Update, and enables you to contact a support professional.

termGrp.term: Centro de soluciones de Microsoft Update

descripGrp.descrip: A feature that provides one-click filtering controls that make it easy to narrow down the portion of a data set that's being looked at.
A miniature chart that can be inserted into text or embedded within a cell on a worksheet to illustrate highs, lows, and trends in your data.
An Outlook Calendar view in which each calendar is listed vertically (not side-by-side). This view is optimized for viewing a schedule for a group and scheduling a meeting for a group.
A feature that converts each slide in a presentation into a single image and rebuilds a new, compressed PPT presentation that can easily be shared, but not edited.

A Windows Media Player (WMP) specific feature that allows you to use the Internet to access music, pictures and videos available on your home network. The feature must be activated on at least two computers in order to work.
A telephone that sits on a desk and is to be used with Lync Server and Office Communications Server.
To gain access to all phone functionality by entering the correct password when the phone has locked itself due to delayed use or when the user has manually locked it.
A numeric keypad that is part of a device, is displayed on a device, or is in a computer program that you use to enter information in the context of a phone call.

An icon that is attached to an event and that is viewable in someone's calendar. Depending on the calendar view, a charm may appear next to an event title, or may be the only visual representation of an event on a calendar day.
An e-mail message that is sent by a notification activity.
A part of a schema that defines the representation of a resource in ILM "2".
An element of a filter that specifies a relationship between data values, such as comparison or equality.
A procedure by which a user's password can be changed to a known value, in situations where the user has forgotten or lost their password.
A feature that allows the application of tags to individual Outlook items to specify retention policy for that message, conversation or other item.
A user interface implemented by a software application via a component of a web server, such as IIS.
A running instance of a workflow definition, when a request is made.

A group of people someone communicates and shares with on Windows Live. Someone's network includes people they've added to their profile, to their Messenger contacts, or both. People in someone's network can see information about their latest activities in the what's new list, and may see other information, depending on permissions settings.
To permit someone else to perform an action. For example, to let someone else see your online status, send you messages, or see your public Messenger information.
A navigation button used to return to recently visited Web pages in Internet Explorer and other internet browsers.
A staging area that contains representations of selected objects and attributes in a connected data source.
The data store that is used by ILM to contain the aggregated identity information from multiple connected data sources, providing a single global, integrated view of all combined objects.

Permissions to use a protected Windows Media-based file in a particular way. For example, a content provider, such as an online music store, can grant you the right to play a song on your computer (a play right), to burn the song to an audio CD (a burn right), or to sync the song to a portable device (a sync right). The content provider dictates the terms of the rights (for example, which rights it grants to you and for how long) and Windows Media Digital Rights Management(DRM) enforces those rights.

termGrp.term: dereitos de uso de elementos multimedia

descripGrp.descrip: A service offered by an online store that lets you rent Windows Media-based files for a recurring fee, after which you can play or sync the files, depending on the service.

Information that describes the current location of a computer. The location is entered manually in Default Location, and can be used by programs to determine the location of a computer when a location sensor is unavailable.

A software system that retrieves information from a source data store and synchronizes (pushes) to a target data store. Examples of synchronization engines are the ILM 2007 and FIM 2010 synchronization engines, and the service that synchronizes data rows in the SQL Server Express database with objects in the Microsoft Office Outlook data store.
To refuse to accept a file or message.
A set of components and services that enable users to access their Exchange mailboxes through the Outlook Web Access application.
A term that can be added to a search to filter the results by a specific property (for example, by author). Relevant search filters appear under the search box in any open folder.
A collection of Internet Protocol subnets, usually used to connect a group of computers that are physically close to each other.
A set of sign-in credentials (username and password) for an Active Directory account.
The identity of a user, which can be used to grant access to resources or authority to perform certain tasks.
A type of corruption that affects the data in the Windows heap, such as damages caused by a buffer overrun, writing to a stray pointer or a double-free.

termGrp.term: danos na área de datos dinámicos

descripGrp.descrip: A soft keyboard that is displayed with a different set of settings by default (larger buttons, bigger size, etc.) when you launch the Tablet PC Input Panel with touch. This is to facilitate touch input.

A two-way device provided by a cable provider that enables some one-way digital CableCARD-based consumer electronic devices such as high-definition DVRs and Media Center PCs to access digital cable channels delivered using switched digital video.
A small, affordable laptop that is designed to perform a limited number of tasks such as web browsing and e-mail.
A real-time, physical action applied to an object, in which multiple contact points are used simultaneously.

A device used to write CD-ROMs. Because a disc can be written only once on these machines, they are used most commonly to create CD-ROMs for data archives or to produce CD-ROM masters that can be duplicated for mass distribution.

A device used to write CD-ROMs. Because a disc can be written only once on these machines, they are used most commonly to create CD-ROMs for data archives or to produce CD-ROM masters that can be duplicated for mass distribution.
A feature that ensures that all components of a file are preserved, even if they are supported only by the rich client and not viewable in Web Companions.
The heading for information about the time at which something was added, changed, or re-posted.
A customizable page that launches with Windows Live Messenger and features a summary of news and weather, allows a customer to preview their Windows Live Mail inbox and search the Internet.
The title of the window in which the Windows Live Messenger Today page is displayed.

A set of features that enables users to improve the quality of their images with just one or two clicks. Galleries help the user optimize characteristics such as brightness, contrast, color, and sharpness.
A feature that enables Tablet PC users to convert an ink drawing to a standard OfficeArt shape, which can be formatted with colors and effects exactly as if it were inserted using “Insert Shape.”

A feature that enables presenters to capture all the elements of a live presentation, including narration, slides, mouse clicks, A/V playback, and laser pointer highlights. The user can select which presentation aspects to record.
A map view created from aerial photos that shows buildings, roads, and geographical features.

A slide show mode that displays content in a manageable window that can be resized and features navigation buttons. This mode is optimized for reviewing presentations, allowing users to get the full experience, complete with animations and media, while performing other tasks, such as taking notes.

A feature that allows users to easily add links to content within other content (e.g. pages, sections, section groups) and provides quick navigation through these links. The feature operates in the same manner that links work in wikis.
A feature that highlights new or changed content in a shared notebook that the user has not yet read.
A high-level linear representation of a project schedule that can be easily formatted, annotated, and copied and pasted from Project into other Office applications.
A feature that identifies the author of unread new or changed content in a shared notebook.

A group of processors commonly used for low-powered hardware, such as tablets and other mobile devices. These small, high-performance 32-bit RISC-based microprocessors are licensed to various semiconductor manufacturers by designer ARM Limited.
The combination of hardware (touchscreen or touchpad) and software elements that provides a way to control programs by touching multiple points on the screen simultaneously.
A predefined collection of audio files (for example, songs) from a CD or digital download.
The name given to the Macintosh operating system, beginning with version 7.5 in September 1994, when Apple started licensing the software to other computer manufacturers.
The street address or geographical coordinates of a user, and (by way of extensions) of the user’s computer or devices.
To save the user's work on a continuous basis, so that it is not necessary to save manually.

A feature that allows users to see conflicting appointments directly from Mail view without having to switch to Calendar view. Makes it much easier for users to decide to accept or decline a meeting invite that conflicts with an existing meeting.
A gallery of effects that users can apply to images to create a customized, artistic look.
A gallery of effects that users can apply to videos to create a customized, artistic look.
A specification according to which each open document occupies its own window in the UI, though only a single instance of the program application is running.
A specification according to which each open document occupies its own window in the UI, though only a single instance of the program application is running.
A flexible bounding box that contains the notes that you type or paste on a page.
A print-to-file driver that enables any Windows application to create XML Paper Specification (XPS) Document files.

termGrp.term: Escritor de documentos XPS de Microsoft

descripGrp.descrip: A tag used to identify a person in a photo.

The heading for the tags that identify people in a photo. This heading is used for the group of all people tags used in someone's photo gallery, and for the group of people tags in an individual photo.
The feature that allows users to stream music, images or videos to a specific device on their home network.
To enter information by means of the keyboard or other input method.

In computer systems, a reduction in level of performance or service. Degradation in microcomputer performance is indicated by slow response times or frequent pauses for disk access because memory is insufficient to hold an entire program plus the data the program is using.
An individual who designs and develops software.
The security account that is used when a data source is configured to connect as a single shared identity for all users.
A video clip that has been inserted into another file or Web page.
An audio clip that has been inserted into another file or Web page.
A standard control that resembles a notebook and lets the user navigate different sections of information without leaving the current element on the screen.
The ability to view data or navigate to or within a physical or virtual computer environment.
An account holder who is a family member, but not a parent, and who has limited use of the Internet. Children can view their own settings, but they can't change them.
An account holder who is the primary administrator (parent) and the family members they manage.
To join or combine thereby increasing the quantity or size of something.
To adjust the action or aspects of a group of items, typically done more than once.
A text box in which someone types words to begin a search.

A “software-plus-services” platform and experience that enables PCs and other devices to “come alive” by making them aware of each other through the Internet, enabling individuals and organizations to manage, access, and share their files and applications seamlessly on the Web and across their world of devices.
The value that is to be searched for in a document or any collection of data.
A UI or media segment that can display on top of or play concurrently with another UI or media segment.
To return to a stable condition after some error has occurred. A program recovers from an error by stabilizing itself and resuming execution of instructions without user intervention.
A feed that provides information, notifications and updates based on people, documents, and tags you are following.
A feed that provides information, notifications and updates based on people, documents, and tags you are following.
A script-based applet that is stored as a favorite or bookmark in a web browser, or is accessed through a hyperlink on a webpage.

The process of associating a feature with a site definition, without modifying the site definition itself or using code routines. The associated feature is added automatically to new sites that are based on that site definition.
A candidate key that is not designated as the primary key and is used to uniquely identify records in a database table.
A text-editing program that lets users create instant messages or blog posts that contain rich text elements, such as text formatting and embedded images.
The link to the form where a user can report violations of the terms of use. Contextually, it's understood that the abuse in question is poor conduct, such as obscene language or threats.
A code that grants rights to an individual, for example to use a system or access stored data.
The web portal from which each company’s service administrator can manage user accounts and settings for each of the Office 365 services to which they subscribe.
A compressed file that can be deployed to a server farm or a site. It can contain assemblies, resource files, site and feature definitions, templates, code access security policies, and Web Parts.
An installation package that the user downloads from http://download.live.com/?mkt=en-us.
The main landing or start page on Windows Live.

termGrp.term: Páxina de inicio de Windows Live

descripGrp.descrip: The button next to a search box that someone clicks to search for something.
A view to which a set of conditions have been applied to reduce the total number of displayed objects.
The status menu item that makes it appear to the user’s contacts that he or she is currently offline.
A process that restricts the flow of data.
The file name extension of a comma-delimited text file.
The file name extension of a dynamic-link library.
The file name extension of a Web page that is an Active Server Page.
The process by which organizations find, retain, and preserve electronic documents related to a legal action.
A telecommunications standard that lets users send and receive messages that include rich text, images, audio, and video.
A web browser designed for use on a mobile phone or device.
The Windows Live service that lets someone set up dynamic photo collections or other media sources to stream into a digital photo frame, or any RSS-enabled device.
A feature that supports automatic eDiscovery based on matches against a fixed search query.

termGrp.term: Suspensión e detección de datos electrónicos

descripGrp.descrip: A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.
A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.
The web browser toolbar that provides quick access to Windows Live services, plus optional features to customize the browsing experience.

termGrp.term: Barra de ferramentas de Windows Live

descripGrp.descrip: Software and the supporting service that enable the synchronization of files between computers and with online storage, of program settings between PCs, and the remote connection to a PC.

The Windows Live service that enables a user to create a personal website where they can create and update a blog, and share their photos, music playlists and more, to connect with friends, family, or the online world.
The Microsoft online service that lets users access and share documents, photos, and other files from anywhere.
The Microsoft online service that lets users access and share documents, photos, and other files from anywhere.
A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.

termGrp.term: Galería de fotos de Windows Live

descripGrp.descrip: A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.
A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.

An instant messaging and video chat service designed for a consumer audience (not for the enterprise). Messenger is available via a desktop app, on the web (no installation needed), and on mobile devices.

An instant messaging and video chat service designed for a consumer audience (not for the enterprise). Messenger is available via a desktop app, on the web (no installation needed), and on mobile devices.
The desktop e-mail program that lets users manage multiple e-mail accounts, newsgroups, and feeds in one place.

An XML file that contains sets of descriptions of one or more external content types, their related external data sources, and information that is specific to the environment, such as authentication properties.
A Windows SharePoint Services or SharePoint Server list from an external content type.
A task page in the Windows Control Panel from where customers can get real-time status information about their network, and also make changes to settings.

termGrp.term: Centro de rede e uso compartido

descripGrp.descrip: The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.
The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.
The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.

The web service where users can share their thoughts, photographs, and interests with all members of a group. Members all contribute to a group profile, and can post blog entries, photos, and other items, just as they can to an individual profile.
The set of Microsoft software for email, instant messaging, photos, and personal movies available to customers in a single download and installation.
The set of Microsoft software for email, instant messaging, photos, and personal movies available to customers in a single download and installation.

The Windows Live universal roaming contact list that allows users to share their contact information and subscribe to others’ to automatically receive updates across Windows Live Messenger and Windows Live Spaces.
The Windows Live service that allows users to make computer-to-computer or computer-to-phone calls. Users must be signed in to Windows Live Messenger to use it.
The Windows Live service that lets people and groups add, manage, and share event information.
The Windows Live service that notifies someone of an event or information based on their subscription preferences. The alerts can be sent to Messenger, Mail, Hotmail, or a mobile device.
The category of services that includes OneDrive, Outlook.com, and Skype.
Pertaining to a search process enabled by a particular technology.
The Microsoft service that facilitates web searches.
The service that allows users to translate text and web pages into different languages using the Microsoft statistical machine translation system.
A form of dialing that uses multiple-tone signaling. The user hears a series of tones (beeps) when dialing.
A form of dialing that uses multiple-tone signaling. The user hears a series of tones (beeps) when dialing.
The website where customers add computers (both PCs and Macs), mobile phones, and digital photo frames so they can access their synced folders and connect remotely to their devices.

A method of managing concurrency by using a cached object's version information. Because every update to an object changes its version number, using version information prevents the update from overwriting someone else's changes.
A SQL Server add-in for Excel.
A SQL Server add-in for Excel.
An employee who in the organizational hierarchy is immediately below the manager in question and who can either be a manager or an individual contributor.

A client organization that is served from a single instance of an application by a web service. A company can install one instance of software on a set of servers and offer Software as a Service to multiple tenants.
A server technology enabling users to load, calculate, and display Excel workbooks on Microsoft Office SharePoint Server.
A feature that makes it possible to detect and restrict specific types of resource usage by individual tenants in a scenario where multiple tenants share a single Web farm of report servers.
A front-end server in CRM that runs a number of server roles, incl. the Web Application Server, Organization Web Service, Discovery Web Service and Help Server.
A back-end server in CRM that runs the server roles, incl. Asynchronous Processing Service, Sandbox Service, and SharePoint Integration Service.
In Microsoft Dynamics CRM, a server that encompasses the Deployment Manager Tool and Deployment Service.
A single physical or virtual server that contains all the server roles.
The hub where site managers can find tools to help with site optimization, blogs from the Bing team, and forums for peer support.

termGrp.term: Centro de administradores web de Bing

descripGrp.descrip: A product for managing the entire lifecycle of user identities and their associated credentials. It provides identity synchronization, certificate and password management, and user provisioning in a single solution that works across Microsoft Windows and other organizational systems.

A product for managing the entire lifecycle of user identities and their associated credentials. It provides identity synchronization, certificate and password management, and user provisioning in a single solution that works across Microsoft Windows and other organizational systems.

A feature that lets users receive and send mail from other e-mail accounts in Outlook Web App. They can add and delete those accounts, check their account synchronization status, and manage e-mail from those accounts in their Inbox using Inbox rules.
A bubble that appears when a user clicks in a field or on a control in the user interface. The Help bubble contains information that helps the user know what to do.

A rule that is defined by an end-user using Outlook or Outlook Web App. When a message that meets the conditions of the rule is sent or received, the rule triggers an action that is performed automatically.
A company that provides text messaging services.
To set again with a different value.
To obtain a new password when the old one is forgotten or expired. As opposed to changing a password, when a password is reset, the user does not get to choose the new password.
The automatic measurement and transmission of data from remote sources by wired or wireless communication means. Telemetry technology is used in a wide variety of applications.
An intermediary between a software publisher and a certification authority (CA). The local registration authority can, for example, verify a publisher's credentials before sending them to the CA.
An intermediary between a software publisher and a certification authority (CA). The local registration authority can, for example, verify a publisher's credentials before sending them to the CA.
To track changes in entities and fields as required.
A tab that is available only when an object in a page is selected.
A solution that is "open" and that can be modified by anybody with the required privileges.

The mode in which certain information is not available for edit on the page until the page is saved after creation. An example of this would be the opportunity record pages, where the opportunity has to be saved before products can be added.
A component that requires the current component to work properly. For example, a dependent component of a global Option Set is an “attribute” that references that Option Set.
A proprietary XML-based query language that is used in Microsoft Dynamics CRM to retrieve information.
A proprietary XML-based query language that is used in Microsoft Dynamics CRM to retrieve information.
A defined point in a workflow that is entered when specified conditions are met.

A feature that uses speech recognition to enable you to interact with your computer or other devices by voice. You can dictate documents and e-mails in mainstream applications, and use voice commands to start and switch between applications, control the operating system and even fill out forms on the web.
A text-based post on Twitter.
A text-based post on Twitter.
An item in the global address list that provides an easy way to send messages to a group of people. A public group can include any item from a global address list, including other public groups.

A voice message that's played to callers to let them know that the person they called is away for an extended period of time and unavailable to answer the phone. It can be customized by the user. It's different from the voice mail greeting that's played when the recipient is away for a short period of time.

A web-based management portal from which a company’s service administrator can manage their SharePoint Online service, including creating and deleting site collections, managing user accounts and storage quota, and specifying service settings.
The Microsoft service that facilitates Web searches on Web-enabled mobile devices.
The Bing service that allows search and view of maps and satellite images.
The Bing service that allows search and view of maps and satellite images.
A type of question (for example, in a poll, survey or test) where the user must select a response from a set of pre-defined options.
A feature that displays a list of frequently used contacts and allows the user to initiate communication directly from that list.
The phone number for a mobile phone.
A group of up to 16 Mailbox servers that host a set of databases and provide automatic database-level recovery from failures that affect individual servers or databases.

termGrp.term: grupo de dispoñibilidade de bases de datos

descripGrp.descrip: A group of up to 16 Mailbox servers that host a set of databases and provide automatic database-level recovery from failures that affect individual servers or databases.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. Captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. Captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
A service that tracks the popularity of notable people and topics based on Bing search data.
To send an instant message.
To send an instant message.
In typography, a single character created from two joined letters that replaces the two separate letters.
A free online service that enables Office users to share presentations with people who view them on the web.
A special-purpose terminal that bank customers can use to make deposits, obtain cash, and perform other transactions.
A server technology that enables users to load, and display Visio drawings on Microsoft SharePoint Server 2010.

An e-mail program originally introduced by cc:mail, Inc., and currently produced by the Lotus Development Corporation. Lotus cc:Mail runs on multiple networking platforms and the Internet and is closely integrated with Lotus Notes collaborative software.

An e-mail program originally introduced by cc:mail, Inc., and currently produced by the Lotus Development Corporation. Lotus cc:Mail runs on multiple networking platforms and the Internet and is closely integrated with Lotus Notes collaborative software.

A legal doctrine that is intended to protect the confidentiality of communications between an attorney and his or her client. The underlying rationale is that by assuring confidential communications, lawyers and their clients will feel free to discuss sensitive legal matters thoroughly.
A function that corresponds to the "Then" part of a rule (If-Then) and is used to specify what is to be done when a condition evaluates as true.

A specific word or phrase that is specified on the basis of an organization's messsaging policy and used in keyword filtering (content filtering) to identify and prevent unwanted e-mail messages from being delivered to users in the organization.
The runspace on the datacenter (host) server, which contains the commands used by the remote user in a client-side session.
The Windows PowerShell session on a user's local computer, which has the basic Windows PowerShell commands available to it.
A mailbox that has been accessed at least once in the last 30 days.
A directory, database, file, or other data repository that is typically offsite and that needs to be accessed remotely.

The Microsoft Identity Lifecycle Manager (ILM) 2007 management agent provided by Microsoft to connect to Outlook Live. It is an ILM component that consists of properties, rules, and rules extensions that determine how an object is processed.

termGrp.term: Axente de xestión de Outlook Live

descripGrp.descrip: The Microsoft Identity Lifecycle Manager (ILM) 2007 management agent provided by Microsoft to connect to Outlook Live. It is an ILM component that consists of properties, rules, and rules extensions that determine how an object is processed.
A person who has a business need to search the mailboxes in their organization for e-mail and other message types that contain specific keywords.

People outside the Outlook Live organization who can be added to public groups and displayed in your organization's address book and other address lists. External contacts have e-mail addresses outside the organization and can't sign in to your domain.

The state that a Windows Live ID takes when the user account with which it is associated is deleted from Outlook Live, but the Windows Live ID for the account isn't deleted. The credentials for that Windows Live ID are still valid and recognized, but the Windows Live ID is put into a forced rename state. If someone tries to sign in using that Windows Live ID and its password, they're asked to rename the Windows Live ID. They can rename the Windows Live ID, but because the new e-mail address can't exist in the Outlook Live domain, the Windows Live ID is no longer functional in Outlook Live.

termGrp.term: estado de cambio obrigado de nome

descripGrp.descrip: An Identity Lifecycle Manager (ILM) 2007 object that has been projected into the metaverse from a connector space object and is linked to at least one object in the connector space. A metaverse entry represents the aggregated view of objects from one or several connected data sources.

The set of numbers found in the MX server field in the MX Record Configuration section on the Domain Settings page of the Windows Live Admin Center. The MX token value is unique for each domain. It is required to create an MX record or a CNAME record at DNS hosting services.

The address by which a Exchange Server recipient object is recognized in a foreign messaging system. In Outlook Live, proxy addresses let people receive e-mail that is sent to different e-mail addresses.

The address by which a Exchange Server recipient object is recognized in a foreign messaging system. In Outlook Live, proxy addresses let people receive e-mail that is sent to different e-mail addresses.

A specially-configured domain that defines settings for mail flow based on the destination domain of each e-mail message. Administrators can configure specific settings for a specific destination domain, or configure default settings for all destination domains. In this way, they can control the types of messages that are sent to adomain. They can also apply message format policies and acceptable character sets for messages that are sent from users in their organization to the remote domain.

A Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) address space or domain suffix that is shared by two different messaging systems. For example, you may have to share the SMTP address space between Microsoft Exchange and a third-party e-mail system, or between Exchange environments that are configured in different Active Directory forests. In these scenarios, users in each e-mail system have the same domain suffix as part of their e-mail addresses.

A Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) address space or domain suffix that is shared by two different messaging systems. For example, you may have to share the SMTP address space between Microsoft Exchange and a third-party e-mail system, or between Exchange environments that are configured in different Active Directory forests. In these scenarios, users in each e-mail system have the same domain suffix as part of their e-mail addresses.
A set of components, for example, entities, attributes, relationships, workflows, and reports, that provide a specific set of functionality on top of the core CRM platform.
A complete solution that has been packaged. After this solution has been installed, the extent to which it can be modified is specified by the publisher.
A solution to which a component belongs to. A component can have only one parent solution.

A solution that contains only selected components. For example, if a user decides to export only a subset of components (for example, some but not all entities), the solution is considered to be partial.
A part of a solution that someone extending CRM can use to achieve specific functionality.
A component that, once protected and installed, cannot be modified.
A solution component that, once protected and installed, can be modified, but not deleted, by a solution.
A deployment-wide container of solutions that can be deployed in multiple organizations.
A partner, such as an ISV, who develops solutions on top of a software platform.
A "catch-all" solution that contains a reference to all unprotected components.
A grid added to a form by a customizer that provides users with access to a group of records, which are usually contextually related.
A narrow and long form that appears in the task pane, which is used to view and edit related data for lookups.
A component that is required for the current component to properly work. For example, a workflow requires an entity to run.
The condition, at a particular time, of an activity.
A service that runs Domain Name System (DNS) servers. Most, but not all, domain name registrars include DNS hosting service with registration.
A service responsible for writing diagnostic logging and usage logging information from SharePoint applications to log files on disk.

A search query syntax that helps produce more precise search results by using targeted queries that search specific properties in a message type. AQS defines certain keywords which can be used to refine the search query, such as specifying boolean operations on searched terms (AND, OR, NOT) as well as to specify further filters based on file metadata or file type. It can also be used to limit results from specific information stores like regular files, offline files cache, or e-mail stores.

A search query syntax that helps produce more precise search results by using targeted queries that search specific properties in a message type. AQS defines certain keywords which can be used to refine the search query, such as specifying boolean operations on searched terms (AND, OR, NOT) as well as to specify further filters based on file metadata or file type. It can also be used to limit results from specific information stores like regular files, offline files cache, or e-mail stores.
A web-based management tool for Microsoft Exchange administrators and enterprise e-mail users.
A web-based management tool for Microsoft Exchange administrators and enterprise e-mail users.
A web-based management tool for Microsoft Exchange administrators and enterprise e-mail users.

The primary navigation tab for mailflow management features in Outlook Live: Transport rules, called “rules” in Outlook Live service; Supervision policies, including closed campus supervision policy and bad words supervision policy, and anti-bullying supervision policy; IP safelisting; Domain types: hosted or shared.

The Web-based management interface for Live@edu administrators. Administrators enroll their domain there initially, and then use the portal to keep their contact information up to date; access DNS record information; view the status of enrolled domains; manage IP safelists; request support for single sign-on; submit or escalate a support request; link to all other resources.

termGrp.term: portal de xestión do servizo Microsoft Live@edu

descripGrp.descrip: A set of e-mail policy settings that can help primary and secondary school administrators comply with some requirements of the Children's Internet Protection Act (CIPA). Using these policy settings, administrators can control who can send e-mail to and receive e-mail from the users in their organization, and filter and reject e-mail that contains objectionable words.

E-mail policy settings that apply inbound and outbound e-mail restrictions so students can send e-mail to or receive e-mail from addresses inside the organization only. Administrators can set up organization-wide exceptions so e-mail can be sent to or from specific domains and public groups. Administrators can also configure per-user exceptions so students can send e-mail to and receive e-mail from specific addresses outside the organization.

termGrp.term: política de supervisión de campus pechado

descripGrp.descrip: E-mail policy settings that administrators use to prevent a bully from sending e-mail messages to specific people by adding the bully's e-mail address as an entry on the "victim's" supervision list. This functionality supports anti-harassment policies in schools and other organizations.

An individual item on the list of e-mail addresses or users that are subject to or excepted from the actions of the closed campus supervision policy or anti-bullying supervision policy. For example, a bully's e-mail address would be an entry on the supervision list of a "victim", and a parent's e-mail address might be added as an entry on the supervision list of their child, who is a student subject to the closed campus supervision policy.
The list of e-mail addresses or users that are subject to or excepted from the actions of the closed campus supervision policy or anti-bullying supervision policy.

E-mail policy settings that prevent sending and receiving e-mail that has specifically banned content. Administrators can use this policy to reject e-mail that contains profanity or other objectionable words, also known as "bad words".

termGrp.term: política de supervisión de palabras vetadas

descripGrp.descrip: A collection of user accounts that are being submitted in a CSV file for migration from an on-premises messaging system to an e-mail system in the cloud.
The action of submitting a migration batch for migration from an on-premises messaging system to an e-mail system in the cloud.
The time span between the start and end dates.
Analytic tools and processes that enable users in an organization to access data to create, use, and share reports without relying on IT for report creation.
Analytic tools and processes that enable users in an organization to access data to create, use, and share reports without relying on IT for report creation.
A SharePoint application service that enables Project Server functionality.
A SharePoint service application that is deployed and managed on premises and that enables enterprise search functionality.
A service application in SharePoint Server that provides unattended, server-side conversion of documents into formats that are supported by the Microsoft Word client application.

A universal security group with administrative rights assigned to it. These administrative rights are specified by built-in management roles, which are part of the role-based access control (RBAC) permissions model in Exchange Server 2010.

A universal security group with administrative rights assigned to it. These administrative rights are specified by built-in management roles, which are part of the role-based access control (RBAC) permissions model in Exchange Server 2010.
A collection of one or more end-user management roles that enable users to manage the settings of their Outlook Live account and public groups.
A special type of mailbox in which copies of the mailbox search results are stored.
The collection of IP addresses that are in a gateway servers list or internal mail servers list of IP addresses that should not be treated as spam.
The collection of IP addresses that are in a gateway servers list or internal mail servers list of IP addresses that should not be treated as spam.

The individual entry on a management role. Role entries provide access to cmdlets, scripts, and other special permissions that let users perform a specific task. A role entry is often a single cmdlet and the parameters that members of a role group can run when the role is assigned to the role group.
The scope of influence or impact of a role assignment. The scope defines what objects a role group member can manage. In Outlook Live, there is the recipient scope and the configuration scope.

A member of an administrator role group, which is a universal security group with administrative rights assigned to it. The roles assigned to the role group are applied to each member who is added to the role group. This grants each user all the permissions allowed by the roles assigned to the role group.
The link to the Microsoft service agreement.
The link to the personal page where users can store information (such as personal interests) and links (such as to friends and photos).
The link to the list of contacts from your mail and messenger accounts.
The link to Windows Live Hotmail.
The link to the list of more links to other Microsoft sites.
The link to the online calendar on Windows Live Calendar.
The link to the online shared event organiser on Windows Live Events.
The link to the online communities on Windows Live Groups.
The link to the user's personal online space, with blog functionality, photo albums, and lists, on Windows Live Spaces.
The link to the site to manage online access rights for, and monitor internet usage of, family members on Windows Live Family Safety.
The link to the site to manage online access rights for, and monitor internet usage of, family members on Windows Live Family Safety.
The link to the Windows Live site where users can register their mobile phone and find information about the Windows Live for Mobile services.
The link to the site to download client versions of Windows Live products such as Windows Live Mail, Windows Live Messenger, etc.
The link to the overview page of all Windows Live, MSN, and Microsoft products on offer.
The link to the page where users enter information for the methods by which they can be contacted, such as Messenger, home phone, mobile phone, and e-mail.

The name of an Outlook Live feature in the Web management interface that enables migration of the contents of user mailboxes from an on-premises IMAP messaging system to Outlook Live (or Exchange Online).

The domain name of the Outlook Live domain that you are configuring with Outlook Live Directory Sync (OLSync)(previously known as GALSync 2010). When you deploy OLSync, you manually enter at least one provisioning domain, for example, student.contoso.edu, during the ILM 2007 configuration process. The provisioning domain must be an accepted domain in your Outlook Live deployment.

A domain or a person that an end user doesn't want to receive e-mail messages from. Messages received from any e-mail address or domain listed in the users' Blocked Senders list are sent directly to the user's Junk E-Mail folder.
An Active Directory security principal object that has at least one associated SMTP address
The name of the administrator user interface in Outlook Live used to import new users with a CSV file.
A comma separated value (CSV) file used to provision many new users at one time.
The process of provisioning new users using a CSV file.

The administrative boundary in which members of an Exchange 2010 role group can make changes. For the Outlook Live hosted service, the write scope is the entire Outlook Live organization. For on-premises implementations of Microsoft Exchange Server 2010, write scopes may be smaller in breadth, such as those defined by a specific organizational unit or a database.
The role group that gives users the permissions needed to use Multi-Mailbox Search.

The role group that gives users the permissions to reset passwords for users and manage settings on the Options page for users' Outlook Live account. To help troubleshoot user issues, members can also view, but not modify, all mailboxes, public groups, and external contacts in the organization.

The role group that gives users the permissions to create and manage mailboxes, public groups, and external contacts. Members can also import new users, track messages sent and received by users, and manage Exchange ActiveSync settings for the organization.
The role group that gives users permissions to create and manage organization-wide rules, also known as transport rules. Members of the role group can also track messages sent and received by users.
The role group that gives users the permissions to manage Unified Messaging (UM) server configurations, UM properties on mailboxes, UM prompts, and UM auto attendant configuration.

The administrator role group that gives users permissions to view, but not modify, all mailboxes, public groups, and external contacts in the organization. Members can also view settings for role assignment policies, transport rules, and supervision policies.

termGrp.term: Xestión da organización só de visualización

descripGrp.descrip: A domain or a person that a user wants to always receive e-mail messages from. Users add recipients and domains to the Safe Senders list.

A feature in Exchange 2010 and Outlook Live that enables users to search the mailboxes in their organization for e-mail and other message types that contain specific keywords. The results of a search are then copied to a mailbox that you have specified so that you can review, organize, and export the search results.

termGrp.term: Busca en varias caixas de correo

descripGrp.descrip: An item that can't be indexed for a mailbox search using Multi-Mailbox Search. This includes unrecognized message types and messages that contain attachments that are encrypted or have an unrecognized format.
A person who is assigned the ability to approve and reject any messages sent to a public group or a dynamic distribution group.

A type of resource mailbox that is assigned to a meeting location such as a conference room, auditorium, or training room. Room mailboxes can be included as resources in meeting requests, providing a simple and efficient way of organizing meetings for an organization.
A person who subscribes to receive updates of another person's activities.
Software or service able to process a large amount of data and provide reports that help users make more informed decisions.
Elevated credentials that have rights to access objects that ordinary users without elevated credentials can't access.

A subscription that gathers messages from POP3 mailboxes and delivers the messages to a designated Outlook Live mailbox so that the Outlook Live end user can centralize their e-mail accounts and only have to check one mailbox.

A Windows Live ID created in a domain, and using the domain name, before the domain was enrolled in Outlook Live. After the Windows Live ID is imported into the Outlook Live domain, it is subject to the security and privacy policies of the organization.

termGrp.term: correo electrónico como identificador de inicio de sesión

descripGrp.descrip: A Windows Live ID created in a domain, and using the domain name, before the domain was enrolled in Outlook Live. After the Windows Live ID is imported into the Outlook Live domain, it is subject to the security and privacy policies of the organization.

The process of validating data before it is processed. This validation helps detect and exclude some errors from the intended process, which might be the import or migration of users using a CSV file, for example.
A DNS server that is responsible for the DNS records that are associated with a domain.

termGrp.term: servidor de nomes de dominio autorizado

descripGrp.descrip: A device that runs Windows Phone Operating System.
The menu item on the Bing menu that links to http://www.bing.com/cashback/.
The Web page object that assists users in finding both public (Web and Windows Live) and private (my Windows Live content) content for insertion into their authored content.
The link to the free online workspace for accessing, editing, and sharing Excel, Word, PowerPoint and OneNote documents across your PC, smartphone, and web browser.
The link to bing.com in some regions but to a dropdown list of more Bing options in other regions.
The Windows Mobile header link that opens a menu that contains more options.
The link to the website where customers add computers (both PCs and Macs), mobile phones, and digital photo frames so they can access their synced folders and connect remotely to their devices.
The link to the code of conduct, which contains rules that explain how someone should behave while using a service or product.
The link to photos that only you and people that you select can view (versus public photos that anyone can view).
The link to the Microsoft service agreement.
The Windows Mobile footer link to the site that is built for viewing from a PC.
The Windows Mobile footer link to the site that is built for viewing from mobile devices.
An activity that includes such information as the description of the resolution and the billable time of the case.
A template that contains the standard attribute of a contract such as billing frequency and allotment type.
Two or more resources (users, facilities, or equipment) that can be scheduled interchangeably.
A scheduling component that is used to view and manage appointments and service activities.
The Identity Lifecycle Manager management agent provided by Microsoft to connect to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) or Active Directory directory service.

termGrp.term: Axente de xestión de Active Directory

descripGrp.descrip: The Identity Lifecycle Manager management agent provided by Microsoft to connect to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) or Active Directory directory service.

A mailbox folder structure on some IMAP servers in which mail folders are accessed with the administrator username and password, and shell login access to the mail server is not allowed. Access to specific mailboxes is managed by access control lists. This means that users are assigned the permissions to only access their mailbox folder, while an administrator has access to all mailboxes. This allows organizations to use administrative credentials to migrate e-mail from an IMAP server to Outlook Live.
The desktop client version of the Microsoft Dynamics CRM product suite for Microsoft Office Outlook.

termGrp.term: Microsoft Dynamics CRM for Microsoft Office Outlook
